callForPapers:
# Call for Papers - NeurIPS 2025

The Thirty-Ninth Annual Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS 2025) is an interdisciplinary conference that brings together researchers in machine learning, neuroscience, statistics, optimization, computer vision, natural language processing, life sciences, natural sciences, social sciences, and other adjacent fields.

The conference will be held at the **San Diego Convention Center** from **Tuesday, December 2nd through Sunday, December 7th, 2025**.

## Topics of Interest

NeurIPS invites submissions presenting new and original research on topics including but not limited to:

*   **Applications**: e.g., vision, language, speech and audio, Creative AI
*   **Deep learning**: e.g., architectures, generative models, optimization for deep networks, foundation models, LLMs
*   **Evaluation**: e.g., methodology, meta studies, replicability and validity, human-in-the-loop
*   **General machine learning**: supervised, unsupervised, online, active, etc.
*   **Infrastructure**: e.g., libraries, improved implementation and scalability, distributed solutions
*   **Machine learning for sciences**: e.g. climate, health, life sciences, physics, social sciences
*   **Neuroscience and cognitive science**: e.g., neural coding, brain-computer interfaces
*   **Optimization**: e.g., convex and non-convex, stochastic, robust
*   **Probabilistic methods**: e.g., variational inference, causal inference, Gaussian processes
*   **Reinforcement learning**: e.g., decision and control, planning, hierarchical RL, robotics
*   **Social and economic aspects of machine learning**: e.g., fairness, interpretability, human-AI interaction, privacy, safety, strategic behavior
*   **Theory**: e.g., control theory, learning theory, algorithmic game theory

Machine learning is a rapidly evolving field, and interdisciplinary submissions that do not fit neatly into existing categories are welcome. In-depth analysis of existing methods providing new insights is also encouraged.

## Submission Types

NeurIPS 2025 invites submissions for:

*   Main Conference Papers
*   Position Papers
*   Datasets and Benchmarks
*   Tutorials
*   Workshops
*   Competitions
*   Ethics Reviewers
*   Affinity Events
*   Creative AI
*   Educational Materials
*   Education Proposals

## Submission Guidelines

*   **Submission Portal:** Submissions are managed through OpenReview: [https://openreview.net/group?id=NeurIPS.cc/2025/Conference](https://openreview.net/group?id=NeurIPS.cc/2025/Conference)
*   **OpenReview Profiles:** All authors must have an OpenReview profile by the full paper submission deadline. Profiles must be up-to-date with publications and affiliations. New profiles without institutional emails may take up to two weeks to activate.
*   **LLM Policy:** Authors must adhere to the NeurIPS policy for the use of Large Language Models (LLMs), available [here](https://neurips.cc/Conferences/2025/LLM).
*   **Paper Formatting:** Submissions must be in PDF format and use the [NeurIPS 2025 LaTeX style file](https://media.neurips.cc/Conferences/NeurIPS2025/Styles.zip). The main text is limited to nine content pages, excluding references, checklist, and optional technical appendices. Camera-ready versions allow one additional content page.
*   **Paper Checklist:** Authors are required to complete a [paper checklist](https://neurips.cc/public/guides/PaperChecklist) for research rigor and transparency.
*   **Technical Appendices & Supplementary Material:** Can be submitted with the paper or separately. No page limit for technical appendices. Supplementary material (code, data) can be up to 100MB. All must be anonymized.
*   **Double-blind Reviewing:** Submissions must be anonymized. Identifying information in supplementary or linked material is prohibited. Citations to concurrent or prior work must be handled appropriately for anonymity.
*   **Dual Submissions:** Substantially similar work previously published or submitted to other peer-reviewed venues is not allowed. Submissions to both the main conference and the Datasets & Benchmarks track will be desk rejected. Slicing contributions too thinly is discouraged.
*   **Anti-collusion:** NeurIPS prohibits collusion between authors and reviewers, with penalties including paper rejection and sanctions.
*   **Author Responses:** Authors will have one week to respond to initial reviews. Responses must remain anonymous.

## Important Dates

*   **Paper Submissions Open:** Apr 03, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Paper Abstract Submission Deadline:** May 11, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Full Paper Submission Deadline:** May 15, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Position Paper Submission Deadline:** May 22, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Paper Supplemental Material Submission Deadline:** May 22, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Affinity Event Application Deadline:** Jun 14, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Expo Calls Open:** Jul 01, 2025
*   **Tutorial Submission Deadline:** Jul 05, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Workshop Application Deadline:** May 30, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Competition Proposal Submission Deadline:** Apr 20, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Datasets and Benchmarks - Abstract Submission Deadline:** May 11, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Datasets and Benchmarks - Full Paper Submission and Co-author Registration:** May 15, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Tutorial Decision Notification:** Aug 05, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Workshop Acceptance Notifications:** Jul 04, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Paper Author Notifications:** Sep 18, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Workshop Mandatory Accept/Reject Notification Date:** Sep 22, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Call For Education Materials Submission Deadline:** Aug 15, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Call For Education Materials Submission Notification:** Sep 26, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Paper Camera Ready Deadline:** Oct 23, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)
*   **Early Registration Deadline:** Oct 11, 2025 (Anywhere on Earth)

## Publication

*   Reviews, meta-reviews, and discussions will be made public for accepted papers.
*   Camera-ready papers must include a [funding disclosure](https://neurips.cc/public/guides/FundingDisclosure).
*   Code and data submission is strongly encouraged.

## Ethics Review

Submissions may be flagged for ethics review, with potential rejection on ethical grounds regardless of scientific quality.

## Preprints

Non-anonymous preprints are allowed but must follow anonymity and style guidelines. Reviewers will not actively search for them.

## Contemporaneous Work

Work published after March 1st, 2025 will be considered contemporaneous. Authors must still cite and discuss relevant contemporaneous work.

## Financial Aid

Students requiring financial support to attend can apply, with at least one corresponding student author needing to confirm their need and agree to volunteer if selected.

## Organizing Committee

callForPapers:
# Onward! Papers - Call for Papers

SPLASH 2025, co-located with ICFP/SPLASH 2025, will be held from **Sun 12 - Sat 18 October 2025** in **Singapore**.

## About Onward!

Onward! is a premier multidisciplinary conference focused on everything to do with programming and software: including processes, methods, languages, communities and applications. Onward! is more radical, more visionary and more open than other conferences to ideas that are well-argued but not yet proven. We welcome different ways of thinking about, approaching and reporting on programming language and software engineering research.

## The Character of Onward! Papers

Onward! Papers is looking for **grand visions and new paradigms** that could make a big difference in how we will one day build software. It is not looking for research-as-usual papers that require rigorous validation such as theorems or empirical experiments. Onward! papers must also supply some degree of validation because mere speculation is not a good basis for progress. However, Onward! accepts less rigorous methods of validation such as **compelling arguments, exploratory implementations, and substantial examples**. The use of worked-out examples to support new ideas is strongly encouraged.

## Selection Process

Onward! papers are peer-reviewed in a **double blind manner**. Accepted papers will appear in the Onward! Proceedings in the ACM Digital Library. Submissions will be judged on the **potential impact of the ideas and the quality of the presentation**.

Onward! Papers follows a **two-phase review process**. At the end of the first phase, papers will be either: accepted normally; asked to perform certain required revisions; or rejected outright. Authors of papers asked to perform revisions will get one month to complete them. The program committee may assign a shepherd or provide concrete revision goals. The second phase is to elevate promising papers, not to require additional work on papers already deemed up-to-standard.

Authors of accepted papers are strongly encouraged to present their work in person at the conference, but remote participation is available.

## Instructions for Authors

### Submission Site

[https://onward2025papers.hotcrp.com/](https://onward2025papers.hotcrp.com/)

### Concurrent Submissions

Papers must describe unpublished work that is not currently submitted for publication elsewhere as described by SIGPLAN’s Republication Policy. Submitters should also be aware of ACM’s Policy and Procedures on Plagiarism.

### Policy on Double Blind Review

Onward! 2025 uses a double-blind submission process. Authors must remove identifying information (names, institutions, etc.) from the author block and refer to their own work in the third person where possible. Acknowledgements should also be removed. The camera-ready copy must not be blinded.

### Policy on Authorship Changes

Any addition of authors after initial submission must be cleared with the PC chair, who has the authority to reject any requested change.

### Format

*   Submissions should use ACM SIGPLAN Conference `acmart` Format, `sigplan` sub-format, and 10 point font.
*   All submissions should be in PDF format.
*   Include page numbers in your submission.

### Page Limit

*   The main part of the paper (excluding bibliographic references) should be no longer than **13 pages**.
*   There is no page limit for bibliographic references and appendices, but reviewers are not obligated to read them.
*   Revised manuscripts and final submissions will be limited to **17 pages**.

## Important Dates (AoE - UTC-12h)

*   **Submission deadline:** Thu 24 Apr 2025
*   **First-round notification:** Thu 24 Apr 2025
*   **Revised submission deadline:** Mon 21 Jul 2025
*   **Final notification:** Mon 11 Aug 2025
*   **Camera-ready deadline:** Mon 25 Aug 2025

## Contact Information

For questions, please contact the Program Chair via [onward@splashcon.org](mailto:onward@splashcon.org).

callForPapers:
# OOPSLA 2025: Call for Papers

The OOPSLA issue of the Proceedings of the ACM on Programming Languages (PACMPL) welcomes papers focusing on all practical and theoretical investigations of programming systems, languages, and environments. Papers may target any stage of software development, including requirements, modeling, prototyping, design, implementation, generation, analysis, verification, testing, evaluation, maintenance, and reuse of software systems. Contributions may include the development of new tools, techniques, principles, and evaluations.

OOPSLA 2025 is part of SPLASH 2025 and will take place from **Sunday, October 12 to Saturday, October 18, 2025**, in **Singapore**. It is co-located with ICFP/SPLASH 2025.

## Submission Rounds and Deadlines

OOPSLA 2025 will have two rounds of reviewing:

### Round 1

*   **Submission:** **Tuesday, October 15, 2024** (AoE)
*   **Author Response:** Tuesday, December 3 - Friday, December 6, 2024
*   **Author Notification:** Wednesday, December 18, 2024
*   **Revision Submission:** Tuesday, February 4, 2025
*   **Author Notification (Revisions):** Tuesday, February 18, 2025
*   **Camera Ready:** Friday, February 28, 2025

### Round 2

*   **Submission:** **Tuesday, March 25, 2025** (AoE)
*   **Author Response:** Monday, May 26 - Thursday, May 29, 2025
*   **Author Notification:** Wednesday, June 18, 2025
*   **Revision Submission:** Tuesday, July 29, 2025
*   **Author Notification (Revisions):** Tuesday, August 12, 2025
*   **Camera Ready:** Friday, August 22, 2025

*All deadlines are firm. New papers may be submitted to either round.*

## Publication

Papers accepted in either round will be published in the 2025 volume of PACMPL(OOPSLA) and invited to present at the SPLASH conference in 2025. PACMPL is a Gold Open Access journal. Authors can voluntarily cover the article processing charge (USD 400), but payment is not required.

## Submission Guidelines

### Template

Use the href="https://www.sigplan.org/Resources/Author/" - SIGPLAN author information page templates. Please use `\documentclass[acmsmall,screen,review]{acmart}` at the top of your paper.

### Page Limit

*   **Initial submissions:** At most 23 pages (excluding required statements, references, or supplementary material).
*   **Revisions:** Up to a maximum of 25 pages.

## Review Process

*   **Double-blind reviewing:** Authors’ identities are only revealed if a paper is accepted.
*   Papers must omit author names and institutions, use the third person when referencing your work, and anonymize supplementary material.
*   Each paper will typically receive three or more reviews.
*   Authors will have an opportunity to respond to reviews.
*   Decisions include: Accept, Reject, Conditional Accept, Minor Revision, Major Revision.

## Reserve Reviewer Policy

For each paper, at least one senior author (PhD completed 5+ years ago) must register as a reserve reviewer on TPMS, unless exempt.

## Data-Availability Statement

Include a section titled "Data-Availability Statement" (not counting towards the page limit) indicating whether an artifact exists, its nature, and whether it will be submitted for Artifact Evaluation.

## Procedure

Please submit using href="https://oopsla2425.hotcrp.com/" - HotCRP .

## ACM Policies

Authors must comply with all ACM Publications Policies, including those on Research Involving Human Participants and Subjects, Authorship, and Plagiarism. Obtain an ORCID iD for all authors.

## FAQ Highlights

*   **Reviewer Criteria:** Novelty, Importance, Evidence, Clarity.
*   **Artifacts:** Not required, but must be explained if not provided when expected.
*   **Anonymity:** Ensure your paper cannot be easily identified by reviewers. Refer to your own work in the third person.

callForPapers:
# NZGDC 2025: Call for Papers

Welcome to the New Zealand Game Developers Conference (NZGDC) for 2025! The conference will be held from **September 25 - 27, 2025**, at **Tākina, Wellington, Pōneke, New Zealand**.

## Theme: The People at the Heart of Games

This year's theme, 'The People at the Heart of Games,' is inspired by the Māori proverb “He aha te mea nui o te ao? He tangata, he tangata, he tangata” (What is the most important thing in the world? It is people, it is people, it is people). This theme emphasizes the human side of game development, highlighting the importance of community, collaboration, and the people who shape our industry – developers, storytellers, players, and cultural guardians.

## What to Expect

NZGDC 2025 will feature:

*   Inspiring talks
*   Engaging workshops
*   Vibrant panel discussions

These sessions will highlight voices from all corners of the industry. Whether you’re a veteran developer, an enthusiastic gamer, or just starting your journey, NZGDC 2025 is the perfect place to forge new friendships, exchange ideas, and ignite your creativity!

## Tickets

[Buy Tickets](https://registrations.nzgdc.com/Public)

## Sponsors

We thank our sponsors for their support of this event and our game dev community.

## Newsroom Highlights

*   **Wellington Games Week 2025 - open!** (June 6, 2025)
*   **Exciting updates as planning underway!** (May 23, 2025)
*   **NZGDC Workshop Submissions OPEN** (May 23, 2025)
*   **Kiwi Game Starter** (Nov 15, 2024)

## Information

*   [About NZGDC](/about)
*   Fly + Stay
*   About Wellington
*   Contact
*   [Code of Conduct](/code-of-conduct)
*   [Photography Policy](/photography-policy)

Join us to learn, create, discover, and connect!

callForPapers:
# NSDI '25: Call for Papers

The 22nd USENIX Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation (NSDI '25) will be held on **April 28–30, 2025**, in **Philadelphia, PA, USA**.

NSDI focuses on the design principles, implementation, and practical evaluation of networked and distributed systems. Our goal is to bring together researchers from across the networking and systems community to foster a broad approach to addressing overlapping research challenges. NSDI provides a high-quality forum for presenting results and discussing ideas that further the knowledge and understanding of the networked systems community as a whole, continue a significant research dialog, or push the architectural boundaries of network services.

## Topics

NSDI invites any innovative solution for a significant problem involving networked systems, including topics from within the following list:

*   Highly available and reliable networked systems
*   Security and privacy of networked systems
*   Distributed storage, caching, and query processing systems
*   Sustainable, low-energy, and low-carbon networked systems
*   Cloud/multi-tenant systems
*   Mobile and embedded/sensor applications and systems
*   Systems aspects of networking hardware and physical layer communication technologies*
*   Network and workload measurement systems
*   Self-organizing, autonomous, and federated networked systems
*   Managing, debugging, and diagnosing problems in networked systems
*   Virtualization and resource management for networked systems
*   Experience with deployed networked systems
*   Networked systems for big data
*   Testing and/or verification applied to networked systems
*   Networked systems for machine learning (ML) and ML for networked systems

*Physical and physical-sensing papers with no clear contributions to the design of systems or the networking stack will be considered out of scope.

The preceding list is not exhaustive. That said, the program committee can reject any papers that they consider to be not in scope and relevant to the NSDI community during the review process. Please contact the PC chairs if you have questions about whether your paper would be in scope.

## Important Dates

NSDI '25 offers authors the choice of two submission deadlines.

### Spring Deadline

*   Paper titles and abstracts due: **Tuesday, April 30, 2024**
*   Full paper submissions due: **Tuesday, May 7, 2024**
*   Notification to authors: **Wednesday, July 24, 2024**
*   Final paper files due: **Tuesday, October 15, 2024**

### Fall Deadline

*   Paper titles and abstracts due: **Thursday, September 12, 2024**
*   Full paper submissions due: **Thursday, September 19, 2024**
*   Notification to authors: **Tuesday, December 10, 2024**
*   Final paper files due: **Thursday, March 6, 2025**

## Submission Guidelines

### Anonymization

NSDI '25 is double-blind, meaning that authors should make a good faith effort to anonymize papers. Authors' names should be withheld, as usual. However, only non-destructive anonymization is required. For example, system names may be left de-anonymized if important for a reviewer to evaluate the work. Specific steps include:

*   Remove authors' names and affiliations from the title page.
*   Remove acknowledgment of identifying names and funding sources.
*   Do not provide links to your own online content; use the submission form for uploads or contact PC chairs.
*   Use care in naming files.
*   Reference past work in the third person, citing anonymously.
*   Reference other submissions as "[24] Under submission. Details omitted for double-blind reviewing."

*Note:* Operational track papers have different rules; content may be de-anonymized as appropriate for the paper.

### Length and Format

*   Submissions—as well as final papers—must be no longer than **12 pages**, including footnotes, figures, and tables. Additional pages are allowed for references and supplementary material.
*   Papers must be in two-column format, using 10-point type on 12-point leading, formatted for 8.5" x 11" paper.
*   Pages should be numbered, and figures and tables should be legible when printed without magnification. Color figures are allowed but should be readable in black and white.
*   A template for LaTeX is available on the href="/conferences/author-resources/paper-templates" - conference paper templates page .

Papers not meeting these criteria will be rejected without review.

### Submission Method

All papers must be submitted via the href="https://nsdi25fall.usenix.hotcrp.com/" - submission form . Do not email submissions.

### Generative AI

Authors must not submit papers generated entirely by generative AI. Authors must submit a statement attesting that their paper is not completely created by generative AI as part of the submission process in HotCRP.

## Review Process

### One-Shot Revision

Each paper may be accepted, rejected, or given the option of one-shot revision. A revision decision includes necessary changes for acceptance. Authors may resubmit a version addressing instructions during the subsequent deadline. This revised paper is reviewed to judge if instructions were met, and on its independent merits. Revised papers can only be accepted or rejected, not revised again. Failure to address revision instructions or introduction of new concerns may lead to rejection.

### Resubmissions

Papers rejected from one deadline cannot be submitted to the immediate next deadline. Papers with one-shot-revision decisions from a prior year can be submitted to the following year's conference, but must provide the previous paper ID. Papers submitted to arXiv or other online repositories must change their title and system name for review to prevent bias.

## Policies

*   **Simultaneous submissions:** Prohibited. Previously published work or plagiarism constitutes dishonesty.
*   **Extensions on workshop papers:** Allowed if the submission includes substantial new material, acknowledges previous work anonymously, and explains differences.
*   **Nondisclosure agreement:** Papers accompanied by NDAs will not be considered.

## Ethical Considerations

Papers describing experiments with users or user data must follow basic principles of ethical research (beneficence, minimal risk, voluntary consent, respect for privacy, limited deception). Authors are encouraged to include a subsection on ethical issues and must attest that their work complies with applicable ethical standards of their institutions.

## Processes for Accepted Papers

*   Invitation letters for visa applications are available upon request.
*   Accepted papers will be shepherded through an editorial review process.
*   At least one author must attend the conference to present the paper.
*   Awards will be given for the best paper(s) and a "Community Award" for papers with publicly available code and/or datasets.

callForPapers:
# OpenSym: Call for Papers (2005-2022)

OpenSym, the Open Symposium, formally the International Symposium on Open Collaboration, and formerly WikiSym, the International Symposium on Wikis, was an international conference dedicated to the research and practice of [open collaboration](https://opensym.org/about-us/definition/). The conference series ran from 2005 to 2022.

All conference proceedings have been published in the ACM Digital Library and are made freely available on this website for convenience and reference purposes.

OSDI is a premier forum for discussing the design, implementation, and implications of systems software, emphasizing innovative research and practical experiences.
callForPapers:
# OSDI '25 Call for Papers

Sponsored by USENIX in cooperation with ACM SIGOPS

The 19th USENIX Symposium on Operating Systems Design and Implementation (OSDI '25) will be co-located with the [2025 USENIX Annual Technical Conference (USENIX ATC '25)](/conference/atc25) and take place on **July 7–9, 2025**, in **Boston, MA, USA**.

## Overview

OSDI seeks to present innovative, exciting research in computer systems. It serves as a premier forum for discussing the design, implementation, and implications of systems software, emphasizing innovative research and quantified or insightful experiences.

OSDI welcomes contributions from a broad range of systems practice, including:

*   Operating systems
*   File and storage systems
*   Distributed systems
*   Cloud computing
*   Mobile systems
*   Secure and reliable systems
*   Systems aspects of big data
*   Embedded systems
*   Virtualization
*   Networking as it relates to operating systems
*   Management and troubleshooting of complex systems

It also welcomes work interfacing with computer architecture, networking, programming languages, analytics, and databases. Contributions with highly original ideas, new approaches, and groundbreaking results are encouraged.

## Submitting a Paper

Submissions will be judged on **novelty, significance, interest, clarity, relevance, and correctness**. Accepted papers will be shepherded through an editorial review process.

A good paper should:

*   Motivate a significant problem
*   Propose an interesting and compelling solution
*   Demonstrate the practicality and benefits of the solution
*   Draw appropriate conclusions
*   Clearly describe the paper's contributions
*   Clearly articulate advances beyond previous work

### Submission Scope and Relevance

OSDI '25 will focus on selecting papers that offer significant contributions to computer systems research and align with community interests. Reviewers will evaluate submissions based on topic relevance and potential impact. Submissions must also demonstrate relevance and offer unique insights to capture the interest of a substantial portion of attendees.

## Important Dates

*   **Abstract registrations due:** Tuesday, December 3, 2024, 5:59 pm EST (10:59 pm UTC)
*   **Complete paper submissions due:** Tuesday, December 10, 2024, 5:59 pm EST (10:59 pm UTC)
*   **Reviews available:** Thursday, March 6, 2025
*   **Author responses due:** Monday, March 10, 2025
*   **Notification to authors:** Tuesday, March 25, 2025
*   **Final papers due:** Thursday, June 5, 2025

## Submission Instructions

*   Papers must be **no longer than 12 single-spaced 8.5" x 11" pages**, including figures and tables, plus additional pages for references. Use 10-point type on 12-point leading, two-column format, Times Roman or similar font, within a text block 7" wide x 9" deep.
*   Accepted papers will be allowed 14 pages in the proceedings, plus references.
*   Papers not meeting these criteria will be rejected without review.
*   **Anonymity:** The review process is double-blind. Authors must make a good-faith effort to anonymize their submissions, refraining from identifying themselves or their institutions explicitly or implicitly.
*   **Supplementary Material:** Authors may upload supplementary material separately. PC members are not required to read it, so papers must stand alone.
*   **Conflicts:** Authors must provide information about conflicts with PC members when registering their abstract.

## Submission System

Papers must be submitted via the [submission system](https://osdi25.usenix.hotcrp.com/).

## Author Response Period

Authors will have an opportunity to respond to reviews before the program committee meeting. Responses should be limited to correcting factual errors, directly addressing reviewer questions, or clarifying the submitted work. New experiments or data are not permitted.

## Revise and Resubmit

OSDI '25 will continue the option for some rejected papers to be revised and resubmitted.

## Related Calls

*   [Call for Artifacts](/conference/osdi25/call-for-artifacts)
*   [Call for Posters](/conference/osdi25/call-for-posters)

## Questions

*   Program Co-Chairs: [osdi25chairs@usenix.org](mailto:osdi25chairs@usenix.org)
*   USENIX office for submission policy: [submissionspolicy@usenix.org](mailto:submissionspolicy@usenix.org)

## Registration Information

*   **Early Bird Registration Deadline:** Monday, June 16
*   Visit the [Registration Information page](/conference/osdi25/registration-information) for fees, discounts, and other deadlines.
*   [Grant Opportunities](/conference/osdi25/grants) are available for students.

## Venue Information

*   **Venue:** Sheraton Boston Hotel, 39 Dalton Street, Boston, MA 02199
*   **Hotel Discount Deadline:** Monday, June 23
*   [Venue, Hotel, and Travel](/conference/osdi25/venue-hotel-and-travel) details available.

callForPapers:
# Call for Papers: PACBB 2025

The 19th International Conference on Practical Applications of Computational Biology & Bioinformatics (PACBB'25) will be held at the **University of Lille (France)** from **June 25th-27th, 2025**.

## About the Conference

Bioinformatics has seen significant growth driven by research in Molecular Biology and Molecular Medicine, leading to an exponential increase in data volume and diversification. Systems Biology is emerging as a critical research area, requiring collaboration between biological researchers and experts in data analysis, mathematical modeling, computer simulation, and optimization.

PACBB'25 aims to promote interaction among the scientific community to discuss applications of **CS/AI** with an interdisciplinary character, exploring the interactions between sub-areas of CS/AI, Bioinformatics, Chemoinformatics, and Systems Biology.

## Submission Topics

Brand new ideas in these fields are sought, as well as substantial and relevant revisions and actualizations of previously presented work, project summaries, and PhD theses.

## Submission Format

*   All papers must be formatted according to the **LNNS template** (Microsoft Word or LaTeX format).
*   Maximum length: **10 pages** (including figures and references).
*   Doctoral Consortium submissions have a maximum length of **6 pages**.
*   Papers must be submitted without page numbers.
*   The template can be downloaded from the submission page.

## Submission Process

*   All proposed papers must be submitted in electronic form (**PDF format**) using the [PACBB conference management system](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=pacbb25).
*   You must upload a ZIP file including:
    *   A signed Copyright Form (**PDF format**).
    *   The final version of your paper (**MS-WORD or LaTeX format**).
    *   A document stating the changes performed taking into account the reviews, using the PACBB conference management system.
*   Authors must fill out and sign the **Consent to Publish** form.

## Review Process

*   All submitted papers will undergo a thorough review process.
*   Each paper will be refereed by at least three experts in the field.
*   Papers will be evaluated based on relevance, originality, significance, quality, and clarity.
*   Submissions must consist of original, relevant, and previously unpublished sound research results.

## Publication

*   Accepted papers will be included in the **PACBB Proceedings**.
*   At least one author must register and attend the conference to present the paper for inclusion in the proceedings.
*   All accepted papers will be published by **Springer** in the **Lecture Notes in Networks and Systems (LNNS)** series.
*   The books of this series are submitted to DBLP, INSPEC, Norwegian Register for Scientific Journals and Series, SCImago, SCOPUS, WTI Frankfurt eG, zbMATH, Google Scholar, and Springerlink.

## Special Issues

Authors of selected papers will be invited to submit an extended and improved version to special issues in different journals, including:

*   Journal of Integrative Bioinformatics
*   International Journal of Interactive Multimedia and Artificial Intelligence
*   Logic Journal of the IGPL
*   ADCAIJ
*   MDPI Future Internet Journal
*   MDPI Sensors Journal
*   MDPI Systems Journal

## General Deadlines

*   **Submission Deadline:** ~~March 7, 2025~~ ~~March 21, 2025~~ **March 31, 2025**
*   **Doctoral Consortium Deadline:** ~~March 21, 2025~~ **March 31, 2025**
*   **Notification of Acceptance:** April 25, 2025
*   **Camera-Ready Papers:** May 9, 2025
*   **Conference Dates:** June 25th-27th, 2025

## Accommodation Grants

CRIStAL Lab offers 15 grants/awards to doctoral and young doctors. More information can be found at: [/open-calls/call-for-grants-awards](/open-calls/call-for-grants-awards)

## Contact

[info@pacbb.net](mailto:info@pacbb.net?subject=[PACBB]%20Contact)

callForPapers:
# PacificVis 2025: Call for Papers

**IEEE PacificVis 2025** solicits novel research contributions and innovative applications in all areas of visualization. PacificVis is a unified visualization conference covering topics including visualization techniques and systems, interactions, analytics and decision support, theoretical contributions to visualization, empirical studies, and visualization applications in domains such as (but not limited to) biological sciences, education, machine learning, physical sciences, security, and social science.

**IEEE PacificVis 2025** will be held in **Taipei, Taiwan** on **April 22–25, 2025**. The conference accepts a range of scientific contributions ranging from full research papers, short papers, and posters. This year, PacificVis has a **TVCG journal paper track**, a **conference full paper track**, and a **short paper (VisNotes) track** with consecutive deadlines. These tracks have separate calls for papers:

*   Call for papers - [TVCG journal papers](TVCG-journal-papers.html)
*   Call for papers - [conference papers](Conference-papers.html)
*   Call for papers - [short papers (VisNotes)](Short-papers.html)
*   Call for papers - Posters

The deadlines for the tracks are arranged so that papers rejected from an earlier track can be resubmitted to a following track (with optional reviewer continuity). All submitted papers will go through a two-stage review process to guarantee the publication of high-quality papers. Accepted papers will be presented orally at the conference and will also be published by IEEE and included in the IEEE Digital Library. Papers accepted in the journal track will be published directly in IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics (TVCG).

## Important Dates

All below deadlines are at 11:59pm (23:59) AoE (Anywhere on Earth).

| Deadline                     | Dates              |
| :--------------------------- | :----------------- |
| Journal track - Abstracts    | **September 15, 2024** |
| Journal track - Papers       | **September 22, 2024** |
| Journal track - Notification | **November 7, 2024**   |
| Conference track - Abstracts | **November 13, 2024**  |
| Conference track - Papers    | **November 20, 2024**  |
| Conference track - Notification | **December 24, 2024**  |
| VisNotes - Paper due         | **January 6, 2025**    |
| VisNotes - Notification      | **February 7, 2025**   |
| Poster - Summary Submission  | **February 21, 2025**  |
| Poster - Summary Notification| **March 14, 2025**     |

Track-specific dates for revisions and camera-ready deadlines are given in the respective CFPs.

## Submission Guidelines

*   **Abstract vs. full deadline:** All tracks except VisNotes have separate abstract (title, abstract, authors, keywords) and full paper deadlines (usually a week apart).
*   **Resubmissions encouraged:** Authors are encouraged to include reviews and responses for previously rejected papers in their submission.
*   **Optional single-blind:** Reviewers’ identities are not revealed. Authors may choose whether to anonymize their submission or not.
*   **Submission System:** IEEE PacificVis uses the Precision Conference System (PCS) to handle the submission and reviewing process. When submitting your manuscript, please make sure that you submit to the intended track.

## Formatting and Language Guidelines

*   **TVCG journal paper track:** TVCG journal format with 9 + 2 pages (with only acknowledgments and references on the last two pages).
*   **Conference paper track:** IEEE VGTC conference format with 9 + 2 pages (with only acknowledgments and references on the last two pages).
*   **VisNotes paper track:** IEEE VGTC conference format with up to 6 pages (including references).

Papers should include full-color figures throughout and we encourage authors to showcase their work with annotated, well described, large, and detailed graphics. We also encourage the placement of a teaser image at the top of the very first page to showcase your work visually. Reviewers appreciate high-quality submissions with correct English spelling and grammar: non-native English speakers may wish to enlist an English language editing service.

## Anonymization

IEEE PacificVis allows both double-blind (anonymized) and single-blind (not anonymized) submissions. Double-blind submissions are intended for those authors who want to submit their work anonymously. Double-blind submissions should NOT include author names or institutions on the cover page of the initial submission, and authors should make an effort to ensure that there is no identity-revealing information (or formulations) in the text. If it is not possible to anonymize without compromising scientific clarity, authors are free to reveal their identities upon submission.

## Originality & Reuse of Text

All submissions must be novel contributions by the authors. This means that they must be original work by the authors that has not been published previously in or submitted concurrently to any conference proceeding, magazine or journal, or the like, in any language, in any form, in whole or in part, by any combination of authors.

A paper is considered published if it has appeared in a peer-reviewed and archived journal, in conference proceedings, or the like, making it available to non-attendees in the form of archives (including digital).

Concurrent submissions (i.e., having the same or a similar paper concurrently under review at another conference or journal/magazine) are strictly forbidden. If it is determined that an identical or substantially similar manuscript is simultaneously under consideration at another publication venue or forum (e.g., conference, journal, edited book), the manuscript will be rejected at an early stage in the review process. Further consequences are possible as well.

Previously published text may not be reused verbatim in a paper submission. Although similarities may be inevitable in discussing background or previous work, the reuse of text can infringe copyright, and is therefore prohibited. Images from published work may only be reused if they are properly cited and the authors have obtained the rights to re-publish the images.

One exception to these prohibitions is non-published preprints (e.g., on arXiv), which do not require citation to preprints. Another exception is theses, which should be cited. The last exception is that preliminary work described in posters, contest entries, or workshops, if not archival, may be resubmitted provided the submission includes substantial additional new material and the previous work is cited.

## Plagiarism Policy

Plagiarism of the work of others is at all times unacceptable and will lead to the submission being removed from the review process. For more information, please see the IEEE Publication Services and Products Board Operations Manual.

All authors will therefore be required to certify on the submission form that the submitted work is the authors’ own work. All submissions are checked for plagiarism and potential cases inspected in detail by the paper chairs.

## Supplemental Material

We encourage the use of digital video to enhance a submission, particularly if part or all of the work addresses interactive techniques. Submission of code, data, evaluation protocols, empirical results, additional figures, or other supplemental material to improve the scientific review of the work is encouraged. Authors are urged to make available salient parameter settings of pertinent algorithms and ideally obtain results using open source data. If specific datasets are employed, we ask that a version of these be made available where possible. Information or pointers to information that can be changed after the submission deadline should not be used as supplemental material.

While most reviewers will take supplemental material into account when conducting their reviews, the authors should ensure that their submission will stand on its own even without this extra material.

## Resubmissions and Reviewer Continuity

Excellent work sometimes requires addressing issues that preclude acceptance within the scope of a single review cycle. For this reason, IEEE PacificVis welcomes revised, resubmitted papers. In particular, given the consecutive timeline of the three tracks, authors are encouraged to resubmit a revised version of a paper that was rejected to one track to the next track. In doing so, the authors can choose to maintain reviewer continuity if desired, in which case one or more of the original reviewers will be engaged for the new review process.

Authors who are submitting papers that have been rejected from earlier PacificVis cycles, or from other visualization conferences, are given the opportunity to include past reviews and a response letter as supplemental material when they submit the revised version. This is not required, but can add continuity and memory to the process so that authors can demonstrate improvement over time even if reviewers change from cycle to cycle.

Note that it is not acceptable to submit a previously rejected paper without addressing the previous review comments.

Reviewers are instructed to not penalize resubmitted papers for past rejections, but instead view the trajectory of a resubmission based on past reviews and author response. However, as with supplemental material, reviewers are not required to take past reviews and response letters into account when conducting their review. Resubmissions should be submitted with information pertaining to the original submission as supplemental material (PDF format):

*   Past submission - previous version of the paper.
*   Previous reviews - complete reviews from the last submission.
*   Cover letter - responses to past reviews (often as summary plus details).

Authors are responsible for the content of the response letter, but effective letters tend to summarize the main points of criticism in the past reviews and explain how the new version of the paper addresses these points.

## Accessibility

We highly encourage accessible final submissions so that your contribution is readable by broader audiences. There are several resources for how to achieve this:

*   [IEEE VIS 2024 - Making PDF submissions accessible](https://ieeevis.org/year/2024/info/call-participation/make-pdf-accessible)
*   [ACM SIGACCESS - Creating an accessible ACM submission using Microsoft Word](https://www.sigaccess.org/welcome-to-sigaccess/resources/acm-submission-with-ms-word/)
*   [ACM SIGCHI - Guide to an Accessible Submission](https://sigchi.org/resources/guides-for-authors/accessibility/)
*   ACM SIGACCESS - Resources for Accessibility

## Generative AI Policy

You are permitted to use generative AI tools such as ChatGPT or Gemini in preparing your manuscript. However, AI tools cannot serve as authors and the human authors bear full responsibility for any writing produced by such tools. In particular, authors are responsible that there is no plagiarism, misrepresentation, or falsification arising from using these tools. Furthermore, the work itself should be a representation of the human authors' intellectual contributions and not the generative AI.

If you do use generative AI beyond merely editing or improving text or generating small passages, you should disclose its use in the paper (such as the acknowledgments or image captions).

## Open Access Policy

Visualization research is better communicated and acted on if it is freely accessible to the research community, practitioners, and the general public. Therefore, all paper authors are encouraged to share their accepted paper in an open access repository before the print deadline in accordance with IEEE copyright regulations. Additionally, funding agencies and research organizations may have specific rules such as Plan S compliance and it is the authors’ responsibility to check and comply with their respective organizational rules.

## Ethics Guidelines

IEEE PacificVis adheres to the IEEE VGTC ethics guidelines for reviewers. In all aspects of the paper handling process, any possible violation of these guidelines is taken seriously and may be reported to the paper chairs for further handling within the IEEE PacificVis organization. Special attention is paid to the identification and reporting of plagiarism; possibly unethical paper content is also monitored carefully in the review process. Investigation and processing of reported cases may lead to an escalation to IEEE.

# Call for Papers - PAKDD 2025

## Welcome to PAKDD 2025

The Pacific-Asia Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining (PAKDD) is one of the premier and leading international conferences for data science, data mining, and knowledge discovery. The 29th edition of PAKDD will be held in **Sydney, Australia, from June 10–13, 2025**.

PAKDD is a prestigious and highly selective conference that includes high-profile keynote and invited talks as well as refereed full research papers. It provides an international peer-reviewed forum for researchers and industry practitioners.

## PAKDD 2025 Features

PAKDD 2025 technical program features a **Survey Track**, and a **Special Track on Large Language Models for Data Science**.

In the new era of generative AI, PAKDD 2025 expects to see substantial submissions on generative AI, large language models, human-like AI, and data science for robotics including humanoid robots, and metaverse technologies. Other typical topics include data cleaning and preparation, data transformation, mining, inference, learning, explainability, data privacy, dissemination of results, theoretical foundations for novel models and algorithms for data science problems in science, business, medicine, and engineering, along with an emphasis on practical yet principled novel models of search and data mining, algorithm design and analysis, economic implications, and in-depth experimental analysis of accuracy and performance. We also invite paper submissions at the intersection of data science and society as part of the main track.

## Important Dates

All deadlines are **23:59 Pacific Standard Time (PST)**

### Main Track, Survey Track, and Special Track on LLMs

*   **Paper Submission Deadline:** December 14, 2024
*   **Paper Acceptance Notification:** February 8, 2025
*   **Camera Ready Papers Due:** March 8, 2025

### Workshop

*   **Workshop Proposal Submission Deadline:** November 30, 2024
*   **Workshop Proposal Acceptance Notification:** December 6, 2024
*   **Workshop CFP Announcement:** December 13, 2024
*   **Workshop Paper Deadline:** February 22, 2025
*   **Workshop Paper Acceptance Notification:** March 15, 2025
*   **Workshop Paper Camera-ready:** March 29, 2025

### Tutorial

*   **Proposal due:** February 10, 2025
*   **Tutorial notification:** February 28, 2025
*   **Submission of tutorial notes:** April 25, 2025

### Doctoral Consortium

*   **Submission Deadline:** February 10, 2025
*   **Acceptance Notification:** February 28, 2025
*   **Submission of Camera Version:** March 25, 2025

## Publication

*   Published by IARIA Press (operated by Xpert Publishing Services)
*   Archived in the Open Access IARIA ThinkMind Digital Library
*   Prints available at Curran Associates, Inc.
*   Authors of selected papers will be invited to submit extended versions to a IARIA Journal

## Contact Us

Email: [pakdd2025@gmail.com](mailto:pakdd2025@gmail.com)

callForPapers:
# Passive and Active Measurement Conference (PAM) 2025: Call for Papers

Original contributions that advance the state-of-the-art in network measurement and analysis are invited for PAM 2025, which will be held virtually from **March 10-12, 2025**.

## Areas of Interest

*   Applications (e.g., web, streaming, games)
*   Data centers and cloud computing
*   Energy
*   IoT (e.g., smart home, SCADA, ICS, embedded systems)
*   Measurement tools and software
*   Network security
*   User privacy
*   Overlays (e.g., P2P, CDNs)
*   Physical Layer
*   Routing
*   Social networks
*   Topology
*   Transport/congestion control
*   User behavior and experience, QoE
*   Virtualization (e.g., SDN, NFV)
*   Visualization
*   Wireless, cellular, and mobile
*   Replicability and reproducibility track

PAM welcomes early-stage contributions, works with operational impact, replications or reproductions of existing studies, and those enhancing the reproducibility of network measurement research.

## Deadlines

*   **Paper registration:** October 1st, 2024 (AoE)
*   **Paper submission:** October 8th, 2024 (AoE)
*   **Notification:** November 14th, 2024
*   **Camera-ready due:** December 10th, 2024

## Submission Guidelines

*   Submissions must be original and not under submission to any other venue.
*   PAM welcomes both short and long submissions, including early-stage contributions and works that validate important results or challenge existing assumptions.
*   Submissions may extend previously published short or preliminary papers.

## Replicability and Reproducibility Track

PAM 2025 features a track for submissions that reproduce or replicate previously published results. Papers in this track must:

*   Clearly state which paper is being replicated/reproduced.
*   Specify whether it's a replication or reproduction.
*   Explain the value of the replication/reproduction to the PAM community.
*   Be marked as such in HotCRP.
*   Include a full citation of the work being replicated or reproduced.
*   Offer comparisons and analysis to the systems, settings, and data used in the original work.

Replication papers will be held to the same technical standards and assessed by the PAM TPC.

## Submission Requirements

*   Follow Springer LNCS format.
*   **Short papers:** Up to 11 pages for technical content (up to 5 pages for appendices and references).
*   **Long papers:** Up to 24 pages for technical content (up to 5 pages for appendices and references).
*   Reviewing will be double-blind. Do not include author names or affiliations. Refer to prior work in the third person and anonymize system names where possible.

## Submission Portal

Please submit your paper at: [Submit via HotCRP](https://hotcrp.dacs.utwente.nl/pam2025/)

## Ethical Considerations

*   Each paper must include a statement detailing ethical considerations. If none exist, this should be indicated.
*   Papers involving users or sensitive data must adhere to ethical research principles: respect for privacy, secure data storage, informed consent, avoiding deception, beneficence, and risk mitigation.
*   Consult the Menlo Report and the Allman/Paxson IMC 2007 paper for guidance.
*   Institutional ethics review body approval is necessary but not sufficient. The PC will assess ethical soundness.
*   If IRB/ethics committee approval has been obtained, indicate this in the ethical considerations section and include the reference number if available.

## Awards

*   **Best Paper Award:** For the paper deemed to have the highest merit.
*   **Community Contribution Award:** For the best paper making relevant datasets, source code, or platforms publicly available with sufficient documentation and archival in a long-lived repository by the camera-ready deadline.

# PDCAT 2025: Call for Papers

We invite submissions of original and unpublished research on, but not limited to, the following topics:

## Networking and Architectures

*   Internet of Things (IoT)
*   Cloud and grid computing systems
*   Edge and fog computing
*   Reconfigurable computing architectures

## Algorithms and Applications

*   Artificial Intelligence algorithms

## Software Systems and Technologies

## Security and Privacy

## High-Performance Systems

## Big Data Management and Processing

## Important Dates

All deadlines are based on Australian Eastern Standard Time (AEST), at midnight on the specified date.

*   **Paper Submission Deadline:** 1 August 2025

*   **Camera-Ready Submission Deadline:** 30 September 2025

## Publication

All accepted and presented papers will be published in the **Lecture Notes in Computer Science (LNCS) series by Springer**. Selected papers presented at the conference will be invited for extended publication in special issues of SCI-indexed journals.

## Submission

Please refer to the submission page for detailed instructions: [submission.html](submission.html)

## Contact

Contact us: [pdcatconf@gmail.com](mailto:pdcatconf@gmail.com)

callForPapers:
# Call for Papers and Special Sessions - PDP 2025

The PDP 2025 conference will be held in **Turin from March 12-14, 2025**.

PDP stands as a premier European and international conference that comprehensively addresses all facets of parallel and distributed processing, encompassing a spectrum from foundational theory to practical implementation, and spanning systems of all scales—from small configurations to the largest infrastructures. PDP addresses fundamental computational challenges alongside robust applications and delves into architecture, compiler, language, interface design and deployment, tools, support infrastructures, and performance optimization.

## Key Focus Areas

Parallel, Distributed, and Network-Based Processing fields have evolved significantly, marked by the emergence of novel architectures and groundbreaking applications. Artificial intelligence (AI) has become a major application area, leveraging parallel and distributed technologies to enhance computational efficiency and enable sophisticated AI models. This progress emphasizes the dynamic fusion of parallel and distributed technologies with other rapidly advancing domains.

## Deadlines

*   **Paper abstracts (main track):** November 5, 2024, 23:59 AOE
*   **Full paper submission (main track):** November 12, 2024, 23:59 AOE
*   **Author notification (main track):** December 20, 2024, 23:59 AOE
*   **Camera ready full papers (all tracks):** January 27, 2025

## Submission Information

For more details about submitting original contributions or Special Session proposals, please refer to the dedicated **[Call for Papers](Call for Papers)** or **[Call for Special Sessions](Call for Special Sessions)** sections.

## Publication

Proceedings of the conference will be published by Conference Publishing Services and submitted for indexing in Scopus. Conference proceedings will be available via the Conference Proceedings link.

# Call for Papers - SIAM Conference on Optimization (OP26)

The SIAM Conference on Optimization (OP26) is scheduled to be held from **June 2–5, 2026**, in **Edinburgh, United Kingdom**.

## Status of Call for Papers

The Call for Participation is scheduled to be posted here in **late August 2025**.

## About the Conference

This is the conference of the SIAM Activity Group on Optimization. The SIAM Conference on Optimization showcases the latest research in the theory, algorithms, software, and applications of optimization. It brings together mathematicians, operations researchers, computer scientists, engineers, software developers, and practitioners, fostering an ideal environment for exchanging new ideas and addressing significant challenges. The conference serves as a platform for specialists and users of optimization in academia, government, and industry to collaborate and share insights.

## Included Themes

**Foundational Themes:**
*   Conic and linear optimization
*   Derivative-free optimization
*   Game theory and equilibrium problems
*   Geometric perspectives in optimization
*   Graphs and network optimization
*   Integer optimization
*   Nonlinear optimization
*   PDE-constrained optimization
*   Polynomial and global optimization
*   Stochastic and robust optimization
*   Variational inequalities and nonsmooth optimization

**Application Themes:**
*   Optimization in data science
*   Optimization in health care
*   Optimization in energy
*   Optimization in control systems
*   Optimization in quantum computing
*   Optimization in science and engineering
*   Optimization in machine learning/AI

## Key Dates
*   **Call for Participation Posting:** Late August 2025
*   **Conference Dates:** June 2–5, 2026

callForPapers:
# PADL 2025: Call for Papers

The 27th International Symposium on Practical Aspects of Declarative Languages (PADL 2025) is a well-established forum for researchers and practitioners to present original work emphasizing novel applications and implementation techniques for all forms of declarative programming, including functional and logic programming, database and constraint programming, and theorem proving.

PADL 2025 will be held in **Denver, Colorado, United States**, from **January 20-21, 2025**.

## Topics of Interest

Topics of interest include, but are not limited to:

*   Innovative applications of declarative languages
*   Declarative domain-specific languages and applications
*   Practical applications of theoretical results
*   New language developments and their impact on applications
*   Declarative languages and software engineering
*   Evaluation of implementation techniques on practical applications
*   Practical experiences and industrial applications
*   Novel uses of declarative languages in the classroom
*   Practical extensions such as constraint-based, probabilistic, and reactive languages

PADL 2025 especially welcomes new ideas and approaches related to applications, design, and implementation of declarative languages going beyond the scope of the past PADL symposia, for example, advanced database languages and contract languages, as well as verification and theorem-proving methods that rely on declarative languages.

## Student Grants

PADL 2025 encourages students to participate in the symposium by providing some student grants to partially cover the registration and travel costs. You can apply by filling out the following form before **December 25**: [https://forms.gle/Xr4HfxgNRxUAy7jv9](https://forms.gle/Xr4HfxgNRxUAy7jv9)

The selection process will give preference to students who present their papers at the symposium. Students from underrepresented groups are strongly encouraged to apply.

## Submissions

PADL 2025 welcomes:

*   **Regular papers:** (max. 15 pages, excluding references) describing original and previously unpublished research results on complex and/or real-world applications, tools/systems, and technical results related to practical aspects of declarative languages.
*   **Short papers:** (max. 8 pages, excluding references) describing original and previously unpublished research results on complex and/or real-world applications, tools/systems, and technical results related to practical aspects of declarative languages.
*   **Extended abstracts:** (max. 3 pages) describing new ideas, new perspectives, or work-in-progress. These will be posted on the symposium website but not published in formal proceedings.

All page limits exclude references. Submissions must be written in English and formatted according to the standard Springer LNCS style: [https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines](https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines)

## Review Process

The review process of PADL 2025 is **double-anonymous**. Authors must omit their names and institutions, refer to their prior work in the third person, and avoid identifying acknowledgments.

Additional material for reviewers (e.g., proofs) may be placed in a marked appendix, which will not be included in the page limit. Reviewers may ignore appendices.

Page numbers (and line numbers if possible) should appear on the manuscript. For LaTeX, authors are recommended to use:
```latex
\pagestyle{plain}
\usepackage{lineno}
\linenumbers
```

The conference proceedings of PADL 2025 will be published by Springer-Verlag in the Lecture Notes in Computer Science series. Work previously published informally may be submitted with notification to the program chairs.

Papers should be submitted electronically via EquinOCS: [https://equinocs.springernature.com/service/padl2025](https://equinocs.springernature.com/service/padl2025)

## Distinguished Papers

The authors of a small number of distinguished papers will be invited to submit extended versions for journal publication in journals like Theory and Practice of Logic Programming (TPLP) and Journal of Functional Programming (JFP). These submissions should be substantially extended (roughly 30%) and will undergo the journal's peer review process.

## Awards

*   **Best Student Paper Award:** Zachary Hansen, Yuliya Lierler: “SM-based Semantics for Answer Set Programs Containing Conditional Literals and Arithmetic”
*   **Best Student Paper Honorable Mention:** Kento Takyu, Kazunori Ueda: “Enhancing a Hierarchical Graph Rewriting Language based on MELL Cut Elimination”

## Registration for PADL 2025

The registration for PADL 2025 is handled separately from POPL. At least one author of each accepted paper must register specifically for PADL.

*   **Early registration deadline:** **December 29, 2024**.

### Registration Rates for PADL 2025

| Type of Registration | Early Rate (British pounds) | Regular Rate (British pounds) |
| :-------------------- | :-------------------------- | :---------------------------- |
| Student               | **£310**                    | **£335**                      |
| Regular               | **£420**                    | **£500**                      |

The registration rate includes the cost of venue, lunch, and morning and afternoon coffee breaks.

### Steps for Registering

Bank transfers can be made to the following account:

*   **Bank:** Natwest (UK)
*   **Bank address:** NatWest Markets Plc, 36 St Andrew Square, Edinburgh, EH2 2YB
*   **Account name:** THE ASSOCIATION FOR LOGIC PROGRAMMING Ltd
*   **Account holders address:** The Association for Logic Programming, Care of Marina De Vos, Dept Computer Science, University of Bath, BA2 7AY
*   **Sort Code:** 60-02-05
*   **Account Number:** 66462738
*   **BIC:** NWBKGB2L
*   **IBAN:** GB74NWBK60020566462738

Transfers usually take a week to complete. For payment queries, contact Marina De Vos.

After the bank transfer, send a copy of the receipt along with your first name, last name, affiliation, and country to gvidal@dsic.upv.es (Cc: cssmdv@bath.ac.uk).

For questions, use the [PADL contact form](https://popl25.sigplan.org/contact2/PADL-2025-papers).

## Important Dates (AoE - UTC-12h)

*   **Abstract submission:** Friday, October 11, 2024
*   **Paper submission:** Friday, October 18, 2024
*   **Notification to authors:** Thursday, November 14, 2024
*   **Final version:** Sunday, November 24, 2024
*   **Symposium:** Monday, January 20 - Tuesday, January 21, 2025

## Programme Chairs

*   Esra Erdem, Sabanci University, Turkey
*   German Vidal, Universitat Politecnica de Valencia, Spain

callForPapers:
# PDPTA'25: Call for Papers

PDPTA'25, the 31st International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Processing Techniques and Applications, is being held jointly with the 2025 World Congress in Computer Science, Computer Engineering, and Applied Computing (CSCE'25) from **July 21-24, 2025, in Las Vegas, USA**.

This conference is an international platform for researchers, scholars, professionals, students, and academicians to share their work and foster working relationships. We anticipate between 1,000 and 1,500 participants, with 21 major tracks, including 112 technical, research, and panel sessions, keynote lectures, and tutorials.

## Submission Invitation

You are invited to submit a paper for consideration. All accepted papers will be published by **Springer Nature** in the proceedings (Research Books) and indexed in major Science Citation Indexation databases (including: Scopus; DBLP; EI Engineering Index; Compendex; Inspec databases; Springer Links; Google Scholar; CP Citation Index, CPCI; part of Clarivate Analytics' Web of Science; ACM Digital Library; IO-Port; MathSciNet; Zentralblatt MATH, and others).

## Submission Website

Prospective authors are invited to submit their papers by uploading them to the evaluation web site at: [https://american-cse.org/cgi-bin/submit/index.cgi?xprint_submit](https://american-cse.org/cgi-bin/submit/index.cgi?xprint_submit)

## Paper Categories and Formatting

For the submission of draft papers (i.e., papers submitted for evaluation), ALL REASONABLE FORMATTING/TYPESETTING ARE ACCEPTABLE. Authors of ACCEPTED papers will later receive specific typesetting instructions to prepare their final versions using the standard Springer Nature typesetting format available at: [https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines](https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines).

Authors can find MS WORD and LaTex templates at the Springer Nature link.

*   All submissions must be original and must not have been previously published or currently under consideration for publication elsewhere.
*   For categories of papers and page limitations, refer to: [https://american-cse.org/csce2025/paper_categories](https://american-cse.org/csce2025/paper_categories)
*   Submissions must be uploaded by the due date (see Important Dates) and must be in either PDF or MS WORD formats.

## First Page Requirements

The first page of the paper should include:

*   Title of the paper
*   Name, affiliation, City, Country, and email address of each author (identify the name of the Contact Author).
*   Abstract (between 100 and 120 words).
*   A maximum of 6 topical keywords (Indexed Terms).
*   After the topical keywords, write the type of the submission (e.g., "Regular Research Paper", "Short Research Paper", or "Extended Abstract/Poster Research Paper").

## Topics of Interest

Topics include, but are not limited to:

*   **Big Data and High-Performance Computing:** Novel computational methodologies, HPC and scalable algorithms for enhancing data quality, models and frameworks for Big Data, graph algorithms, computational science, computational intelligence, Scalable systems and architectures for Big Data, etc.
*   **Parallel/Distributed Applications:** Numerical computations/methods, neural networks and fuzzy logic, medicine, remote sensing, computer vision, computer graphics and virtual reality, parallel/distributed databases, banking, financial markets, high-performance computational biology, etc.
*   **Parallel/Distributed Architectures:** Clusters and parallel systems of various topologies, supercomputers, shared memory, distributed memory, general- and special-purpose architectures, instructional level parallelism, etc.
*   **Networks and Interconnection Networks:** Scalable networks, reconfigurable networks, routing issues, general-purpose network performance for distributed applications, network protocols, internet technology, optical interconnections and computing, novel network topologies, etc.
*   **Energy/power-aware Computing:** Energy-aware resource management, green computing, energy efficiency planning, energy-aware technologies, low power virtualization and software techniques, low power logic/circuit/process technology design, methods and tools for forecasting, estimating, and validating power use, etc.
*   **Reliability and Fault-tolerance:** Software and hardware fault-tolerance (system- and application-level), fault diagnosis, fault-tolerance measurement.
*   **Building Block Processors:** Applications of processors that can be used as basic building blocks for multicomputer systems.
*   **Real-time and Embedded Systems:** Small-scale parallel systems for high-performance control, data acquisition, and analysis; configuration, routing, scheduling, performance guarantees, etc.
*   **Parallel/Distributed Algorithms:** Algorithms exploiting clusters and general-purpose distributed and parallel systems, new vector/pipeline issues, shared memory, distributed memory, virtual memory, etc.
*   **Multimedia Communications, Systems, and Applications:** High-speed networking, multimedia architectures and protocols, multimedia applications, quality of service support, operating system and networking support, internet tools and applications, audio/video delivery over the internet, etc.
*   **Software Tools and Environments for Parallel and Distributed Platforms:** Operating systems, compilers, languages, debuggers, monitoring tools, software engineering on parallel/distributed systems, etc.
*   **High-performance Computing in Computational Science:** Intra-disciplinary and multi-disciplinary research programs and applications.
*   **Performance Evaluation and Management of Wireless Networks and Distributed Systems.**
*   **FPGA-based Design.**
*   **Performance Analysis, Evaluation, Prediction, ...**
*   **Nanotechnology in HPC.**
*   **High-performance Mobile Computation and Communication.**
*   **Object Oriented Technology and Related Issues.**
*   **Scheduling and Resource Management.**
*   **Petri Nets: Theory, Analysis, Tools and Applications.**
*   **Web-based Simulation and Computing.**
*   **Cloud Computing.**
*   **Complex Systems, Theory and Applications.**
*   **Other Aspects and Applications relating to High-Performance Computations.**
*   **Emerging Technologies.**

## Presentation Modes

This year's Congress will be held in person (face-to-face); however, online presentation options will also be available for authors and speakers who are unable to attend physically. Refer to [https://american-cse.org/csce2025/presentation_modes](https://american-cse.org/csce2025/presentation_modes) for details.

## Contact Information

Questions and inquiries should be sent to: CSCE'25 Conference Secretariat: [cs@american-cse.org](mailto:cs@american-cse.org)

callForPapers:
# IFIP PERFORMANCE 2025: Call for Papers

The IFIP International Symposium on Computing Performance, Modelling, Measurement and Evaluation (PERFORMANCE 2025) will be held at the **Centrum Wiskunde & Informatica (CWI) in Amsterdam (NL) on November 11-14, 2025**.

This conference aims to bring together researchers interested in understanding and improving the performance of computing and communication systems using state-of-the-art quantitative models and solution techniques.

## Submission Categories

We invite submissions of original and unpublished work in two categories:

*   **Regular papers:** 20 pages
*   **Short papers:** 5 pages in the new PER double-column format (formerly 10 pages)

## Important Dates

*   **Submission site opens:** May 1, 2025
*   **Abstract submission:** June 8, 2025
*   **Full paper submission:** June 15, 2025
*   **Notification to authors:** July 30, 2025

## Topics of Interest

Topics of interest include, but are not limited to, the following:

### Performance-oriented methodologies

*   Analytical modeling techniques and model validation
*   Anomaly detection, problem diagnosis, and troubleshooting
*   Capacity planning, resource allocation, routing, scheduling, and quality of service
*   Experimental design, statistical analysis, simulation
*   Game theory, network economics, and platform design
*   Machine learning, data mining, graph analysis, optimization
*   Performance, scalability, power, and reliability analysis
*   Stochastic modeling, statistical analysis, and simulation
*   Sustainability analysis and power management
*   Complex networks, sorting, and ranking
*   System measurement, performance monitoring, and forecasting
*   Workload characterization and benchmarking

### Evaluation techniques and algorithms for:

*   Artificial intelligence and machine learning platforms
*   Blockchains and crypto-currency
*   Computer architectures and operating systems
*   Cyber-physical systems, the Internet of Things, and smart grids
*   Data centers, content delivery, cloud computing, and virtualization
*   High-performance computing
*   Internet and web services
*   Mobile and personal computing systems
*   Network architectures, protocols, and congestion control
*   Network economics and platform design
*   Privacy and algorithmic fairness
*   Security systems
*   Storage systems and data centers
*   Social networks, multimedia systems, and smart grid
*   Virtualization, data centers, distributed and cloud computing, fog, and edge computing
*   Quantum computing and quantum communication
*   Wireless, ad-hoc, and cellular networks

## Submission Guidelines

*   Submissions must be made through the online **href="https://performance2025.hotcrp.com/" - hotCRP platform** in printable PDF form.
*   **Double-blind review process:** Authors’ names and affiliations should not appear in the paper, and bibliographic references should be made in such a way as to preserve author anonymity. References to your own past work should be made in the third person.
*   Authors must declare conflicts with TPC members truthfully on the submission page.
*   Publication of a pre-submission version on your personal website, institutional archive, or arXiv is allowed, but authors should be mindful of not broadcasting this information widely.

## Paper Formatting

### Regular Papers

*   Maximum 20 pages for technical content (excluding references).
*   Recommended to use the **Elsevier article class elsarticle.cls** (with the 3p document class option) and BibTeX for bibliographies.
*   An appendix of unrestricted length can be included for technical correctness, but reviewers are not obligated to review it.

### Short Papers

*   Limited to 5 pages (PER double-column format) for technical content (excluding references).
*   An appendix of unrestricted length can be included for technical correctness, but reviewers are not obligated to review it.
*   Accepted short papers will be published in a special ACM Performance Evaluation Review (PER) issue.

## Conference Format

The conference will be fully **on-site**. At least one author of each accepted paper is expected to attend the conference and present the work.

## Special Issues

Accepted regular papers will be published in a special **Performance Evaluation (PEVA) issue**. Authors may opt-out of publication in PEVA for an expedited review process in journals related to Performance Evaluation and Operations Research, such as:

*   **href="https://tompecs.acm.org/" - ACM Transactions on Modeling and Performance Evaluation of Computer Systems (ToMPECS)**
*   Queueing Systems: Theory and Application (QUESTA)
*   Stochastic Models

## Policies

### Soft Tracking

Authors must select a track (Learning, Measurement & Applied Modelling, Systems, Theory) when submitting their paper. A second track can optionally be selected for inter-disciplinary papers.

### Anonymity Guidelines

Follow standard double-blind review practices: remove names, affiliations, and acknowledgments. Use care in file naming and referencing own work (third person).

### Ethical Considerations

Papers describing experiments with users or user data should adhere to ethical research principles, including beneficence, minimal risk, voluntary consent, respect for privacy, and limited deception. Authors are encouraged to include a subsection describing these issues and must attest that their work complies with applicable ethical standards.

### Diversity & Inclusiveness

Guidelines are provided to promote inclusivity in technical writing, including using gender-neutral language, diverse names, and avoiding assumptions about binary gender or traditional family structures. Accessibility guidelines emphasize using patterns, symbols, and textures in figures, avoiding poor color combinations, and ensuring graphs are readable in monochrome.
