callForPapers:
# Call for Papers: PEPM 2025

The ACM SIGPLAN Workshop on Partial Evaluation and Program Manipulation (PEPM) is a workshop with a history dating back to 1991, held in conjunction with POPL since 2006. PEPM focuses on semantics-based program manipulation, exploring techniques for generating, analyzing, and transforming programs while maintaining semantic properties.

## Scope

PEPM 2025 welcomes submissions in both traditional PEPM topics and new domains.

**Traditional Topics include, but are not limited to:**
*   Program and model manipulation techniques such as: supercompilation, partial evaluation, fusion, on-the-fly program adaptation, active libraries, program inversion, slicing, symbolic execution, refactoring, decompilation, and obfuscation.
*   Techniques treating programs/models as data objects: metaprogramming, generative programming, embedded domain-specific languages (DSLs), program synthesis by sketching and inductive programming, staged computation, and model-driven program generation and transformation.
*   Program analysis techniques for driving manipulation: abstract interpretation, termination checking, binding-time analysis, constraint solving, type systems, automated testing and test case generation.
*   Applications and case studies: real-world projects, robust tools, benchmarking, legacy program understanding, DSL implementations, visual languages, end-user programming, scientific computing, middleware, embedded systems, and security.

**New Domains include:**
*   Semantics-based and machine-learning-based program synthesis and program optimization.
*   Modeling, analysis, and transformation techniques for distributed and concurrent protocols and programs, such as session types, linear types, and contract specifications.

The workshop encourages submissions describing new theories and applications related to semantics-based program manipulation in general. For inquiries, contact the program co-chairs: Guillaume Allais (guillaume.allais@strath.ac.uk) and Annie Liu (liu@cs.stonybrook.edu).

## Submission Types and Guidelines

Three types of submissions will be accepted:

1.  **Regular Research Papers:**
    *   Describe new results, judged on originality, correctness, significance, and clarity.
    *   **Page Limit:** Maximum 12 pages (excluding references and appendices).
    *   **Publication:** Appear in formal proceedings published by ACM and included in the ACM Digital Library.

2.  **Short Papers:**
    *   May include tool demonstrations, presentations of emerging research, or interesting academic, industrial, and open-source applications.
    *   **Page Limit:** Maximum 6 pages (excluding references and appendices).
    *   **Publication:** Do not constitute formal publications and will not appear in the proceedings.

3.  **Talk Proposals:**
    *   Propose lectures on topics of interest, existing relevant contributions, or promising work not yet mature for papers.
    *   **Page Limit:** Maximum 2 pages (excluding references).

**Formatting:**
*   Typeset using the two-column ‘sigplan’ sub-format of the ACM ‘acmart’ format. Template available at: [http://sigplan.org/Resources/Author/](http://sigplan.org/Resources/Author/)

**Submission System:**
*   Submit electronically via HotCRP: [https://pepm25.hotcrp.com](https://pepm25.hotcrp.com)

**Reviewing:**
*   **Process:** Single-blind reviewing.
*   **Eligibility:** Submissions are welcome from PC members (except the two co-chairs).

**Presentation Requirement:**
*   At least one author of each accepted contribution must attend the workshop (physically or virtually) to present the work.
*   For tool demonstration papers, a live demonstration is expected.

## Important Dates (AoE - UTC-12h)

*   **Abstract Deadline:** Monday, 14 October 2024
*   **Submission Deadline:** Friday, 18 October 2024
*   **Author Notification:** Monday, 18 November 2024
*   **Camera Ready Version:** Wednesday, 4 December 2024
*   **Workshop Date:** Tuesday, 21 January 2025

## Invited Speakers

*   William Bowman – University of British Columbia
*   Brigitte Pientka – McGill University
*   Satnam Singh – Groq

## Chairs

*   **General Chairs:**
    *   Guillaume Allais (University of Strathclyde, United Kingdom)
    *   Y. Annie Liu (Stony Brook University, United States)

## Contact

For questions, please use the PEPM contact form: [https://popl25.sigplan.org/contact2/pepm-2025-papers](https://popl25.sigplan.org/contact2/pepm-2025-papers)

callForPapers:
# Call for Papers: IEEE PerCom 2026

The **24th International Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications (PerCom 2026)**, the premier annual scholarly venue in pervasive computing and communications, will be held at the **National Research Council Area, Pisa, Italy** from **March 16 – 20, 2026**, as a physical in-person conference.

PerCom is at the forefront of mobile systems research, driven by advances in wireless networking, mobile and distributed computing, sensor systems, ambient intelligence, and smart devices.

## Scope and Topics

PerCom 2026 solicits research contributions in all areas pertinent to pervasive computing and communications, especially those that cross traditional research boundaries. Key areas include:

*   **Advances in Pervasive Systems and Infrastructures:** Middleware systems and services; data engineering for pervasive computing; cloud, fog, and edge computing; integrations of smartphones in pervasive experiences; applications of device-to-device coordination.
*   **Theories, Models, and Algorithms:** Context modeling & reasoning; adaptive computing; activity & emotion recognition; programming paradigms; applied deep/federated/decentralized machine learning; causal learning; cognitive computing; complex networks; spatio-temporal modeling.
*   **Domain-Specific Challenges and Novel Applications:** Urban/mobile crowdsensing & intelligence; PerCom for healthcare and well-being; cyber-physical systems; PerCom for space applications, smart homes and virtual assistants; mixed reality; sports analytics; crime prevention; pervasive nowcasting; urban robotics; pervasive AR/VR; smart vehicles; disaster sensing and management.
*   **Intersections of PerCom:** IoT and sensor systems; Large Language Models; opportunistic networks; pervasive data science; cyber-physical systems; 3D networks.
*   **Enablers for PerCom Instrumentation:** Security, privacy, and trust in Pervasive Computing; ethical aspects of Pervasive Computing.
*   **New Techniques for User-Level Concerns:** Participatory and social sensing; fairness and ethics; user interface, interaction, and persuasion; online and offline social networking; human-machine collaboration.
*   **Technological Innovations:** Architectures, protocols, and technologies for pervasive communications; energy-harvesting, self-powered, or battery-less systems; mobile and wearable systems; smart devices and environments; positioning, navigation, timing, and tracking technologies; device-free human sensing.

Contributions can be analytical, empirical, technological, methodological, or a combination thereof. Papers reporting strong systems engineering contributions backed by solid and appropriate evaluations are strongly encouraged.

Contributions must be **novel**, demonstrate a **significant impact**, and be **rigorous**, with impact demonstrated in the context of pervasive computing and communications applications.

## Important Dates

*   **Paper registration in EDAS:** **September 12, 2025** (AoE)
*   **Submission via EDAS:** **September 19, 2025** (AoE)
*   **1st stage notification:** **November 28, 2025** (AoE)
*   **Rebuttal submission:** **December 5, 2025** (AoE)
*   **Final notification:** **December 22, 2025** (AoE)
*   **Camera Ready:** **February 2, 2026** (AoE)

## Submission Guidelines

*   **Submission Platform:** All paper submissions must be done for the main conference and all associated events via [EDAS](https://edas.info/). If you do not have an EDAS account, please register first [here](https://edas.info/register). The direct submission link for PerCom 2026 is [here](https://percom.org/submission-instructions/).
*   **Review Process:** PerCom 2026 will follow a **double-blind review process**. Authors are expected to make a good-faith effort to anonymize their submissions. Pre-prints on online archives like arXiv are permitted.
*   **Originality:** Submitted papers must be unpublished and not considered elsewhere for publication.
*   **Format:** Only electronic submissions in PDF format will be considered. Use the [IEEE LaTeX and Microsoft Word templates](https://percom.org/submission-instructions/).
*   **Length:** Papers must be at most **9 pages** of technical content (10pt font, 2-column format), including figures and tables, and up to **1 additional page for references** only.
*   **Rebuttal Phase:** Authors will have the opportunity to respond to initial reviews.
*   **Presentation:** All accepted papers **must be presented in person** by one of the authors. Failure to comply will result in exclusion from the proceedings and awards.

## Awards and Publication

*   **Best Paper Award:** The best paper will receive the prestigious Mark Weiser Best Paper Award.
*   **Journal Submission:** Selected papers will be invited to submit extended versions for a special issue of the *Pervasive and Mobile Computing Journal*.
*   **Publication:** Accepted papers will be published in IEEE Xplore. Artifacts associated with contributions should be submitted separately.

## Contact

*   General Contact: [ieeepercom@gmail.com](mailto:ieeepercom@gmail.com)
*   TPC Chairs: [percom2026-tpc-chairs@fbk.eu](mailto:percom2026-tpc-chairs@fbk.eu)

The PDF version of the Call for Papers can be found [here](https://percom.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Percom2026CFP_v6.pdf).

# Call for Papers

The 36th edition of the annual IEEE International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC) will be held in **Istanbul, Türkiye, from September 1-4, 2025**.

PIMRC is one of the major conferences of the IEEE Communications Society, attracting technical communities from all regions and continents. It focuses on cutting-edge wireless technology research and innovations, covering wireless and mobile communications, applications, services, and business.

Prospective authors are invited to submit original technical papers, as well as proposals for special sessions, workshops, tutorials, and industry panels.

## Topics of Interest

**Track 1: Fundamentals and PHY**

*   AI and ML in/for communications
*   Coding/modulation, information theory
*   Channel modeling and equalization
*   Cooperative communications, coded caching/computing
*   Integrated sensing and communications
*   Millimeter wave and Terahertz communications
*   Multi-user communications and interference mitigation
*   Optical wireless and visible light communications
*   Physical layer security
*   Propagation, antennas and beamforming
*   Quantum communications
*   Semantic communications and signal processing
*   Source coding and joint source-channel coding
*   Synchronization techniques
*   Ultra-wideband communications
*   Ultra/Tera multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO)
*   Wireless information and power transfer

**Track 2: MAC and Cross Layer Design**

*   Adaptive and reconfigurable MAC
*   Age of information aware MAC design
*   Information-theoretic approaches to MAC design
*   Joint access and backhaul scheduler design
*   Joint MAC and networking layer design
*   MAC for low-power embedded networks
*   MAC for mobile and vehicular networks
*   ML for resource management
*   Next-generation multiple access
*   Radio resource management, allocation, and scheduling
*   Scheduler for cooperative and relay systems
*   Security issues in MAC design

**Track 3: Mobile and Wireless Networks**

*   Ad hoc networks and wireless sensor networks
*   Cognitive radio networks and self-organizing networks
*   Cooperative networking
*   Data-driven, large-scale network modelling and optimization
*   Digital twins and autonomous networks
*   Green and energy-efficient networks
*   Massive Internet of Things (IoT) and sensor networks
*   ML for networking, distributed ML, multi-agent systems
*   Mobile edge, cloud, and fog computing
*   Network security
*   O-RAN
*   Software-defined and open interface-based networks
*   Stochastic geometry

**Track 4: Emerging Technologies, Applications and Platforms**

*   5G NR and 6G standardization
*   802.11 and next-generation Wi-Fi

*   Experiments, prototypes, and testbeds
*   Fluid antenna communications
*   Full-duplex communication networks
*   Holographic MIMO
*   Innovative implanted and wearable devices
*   Intelligent beamforming relays
*   Joint radar and communications
*   Networking support for virtual and augmented reality
*   Reconfigurable intelligent surfaces
*   Sensing and localization
*   Software defined radio and networks
*   Surface wave communications

## Submission Types

*   Original technical papers
*   Proposals for special sessions
*   Workshop proposals
*   Workshop papers

## Further Information

For more details, please download the Call for Papers: [Download Call for Papers](https://pimrc2025.ieee-pimrc.org/sites/pimrc2025.ieee-pimrc.org/files/PIMRC%202025%20-%20Call%20for%20Papers%20-%20March%2031%20version.pdf)

callForPapers:
# PLOS 2025: Call for Papers

The 13th Workshop on Programming Languages and Operating Systems (PLOS 2025) will be held on **October 13, 2025**, in **Seoul, Republic of Korea**, in conjunction with the **31st ACM Symposium on Operating Systems Principles (SOSP '25)**.

## Rationale

Historically, operating system (OS) development and programming language (PL) development went hand-in-hand, fostering cross-fertilization. Challenges in one area were often approached using ideas or techniques developed in the other, and advances in one enabled new capabilities in both. Today, although the systems community at large retains an iron grip on C, modern PL ideas continue to spark innovations in OS design and construction. Conversely, the systems field continues to provide a wealth of challenging problems and practical results that should spark advances in PLs, software designs, and idioms.

This workshop will bring together researchers and developers from the PL and OS domains to discuss recent work at the intersection of these fields. It will be a venue for discussing new visions, challenges, experiences, problems, and solutions arising from the application of advanced programming and software engineering concepts to OSes construction, and vice versa.

## Important Dates (tentative)

*   **Submission:** July 25, 2025
*   **Notification:** August 25, 2025
*   **Workshop:** October 13, 2025

## Venue and Registration

PLOS 2025 is co-located with SOSP '25, and registration will be handled via the SOSP registration site once it is available.

## Submission

Submissions are encouraged for the intersection of programming languages and operating systems. The call for papers is online (PDF available) with a submission deadline of July 25, 2025.

callForPapers:
# Call for Papers

## Overview

Welcome to the home page of the 46th ACM SIGPLAN Conference on Programming Language Design and Implementation (PLDI 2025)!

PLDI is the premier forum in the field of programming languages and programming systems research, covering the areas of design, implementation, theory, applications, and performance.

PLDI 2025 will be held in-person at the Westin Josun Seoul in Seoul, South Korea.

The main PLDI conference will be held **Wednesday, 18 June through Friday, 20 June**. Workshops and tutorials were held on **Monday, 16 June and Tuesday, 17 June**.

## Scope

PLDI is a premier forum for programming language research, broadly construed. Outstanding research that extends and/or applies programming-language concepts to advance the field of computing is welcome. Novel system designs, thorough empirical work, well-motivated theoretical results, and new application areas are all in scope for PLDI.

## Submission Process

### Deadlines

All deadlines are **Anywhere on Earth (UTC-12h)**:

*   **Submission Deadline:** **Thursday, November 14, 2024**
*   **Author Response Period:** **Tuesday, 18 - Saturday, 22 February 2025**
*   **Notification to Authors:** **Thursday, 6 March 2025**
*   **Camera-Ready Deadline:** **Thursday, 10 April 2025**

### Submission Site

The submission site will be at [https://pldi25.hotcrp.com/](https://pldi25.hotcrp.com/).

Authors can submit multiple times prior to the (firm!) deadline. Only the last submission will be reviewed. There is no deadline for submitting abstracts. The submission site requires entering author names and affiliations, relevant topics, and potential conflicts. Addition or removal of authors after the submission deadline will need to be approved by the Associate Editor.

### Declaring Conflicts

When submitting a paper, you will need to declare potential conflicts. Conflicts should be declared between an adviser and an advisee (e.g., Ph.D., post-doc). Other conflicts include institutional conflicts, financial conflicts of interest, friends or relatives, or any recent co-authors on papers and proposals (last 2 years).

Please do not declare spurious conflicts: such incorrect conflicts are especially harmful if the aim is to subvert the normal peer-review process by excluding potential reviewers. Listing spurious conflicts can be grounds for rejection. If you are unsure about whether or not a given relationship constitutes a conflict, please consult the Associate Editor.

## Formatting Requirements

### Page Limits and Layout

Each paper should have no more than **20 pages of text**, excluding bibliography, using the ACM Proceedings format. This format is chosen for compatibility with PACMPL. It is a single-column page layout with a 10 pt font, 12 pt line spacing, and wider margins than recent PLDI page layouts. In this format, the main text block is 5.478 in (13.91 cm) wide and 7.884 in (20.03 cm) tall.

Use of a different format (e.g., smaller fonts or a larger text block) is grounds for summary rejection.

### Templates

PACMPL templates for Microsoft Word and LaTeX can be found at the [SIGPLAN author information page](https://www.sigplan.org/Resources/Author/). Authors using LaTeX should use the `sample-acmsmall-conf.tex` file (found in the samples folder of the acmart package) with the `acmsmall` option. We also strongly encourage use of the `review` and `screen` options as well, e.g.:

```latex
\documentclass[acmsmall,screen,review,anonymous,nonacm]{acmart}
```

### Citations

Papers may be submitted using numeric citations, but final versions of accepted papers may use either the author-year or numeric format for citations.

### File Format

Submissions should be in **PDF** and printable on both US Letter and A4 paper. Please take care to ensure that figures and tables are legible, even when the paper is printed in gray-scale.

### Late/Incorrect Submissions

Papers that exceed the length requirement, deviate from the expected format, or are submitted late will be rejected.

## Review Process

### Evaluation Criteria

Reviewers will evaluate submissions for accuracy, significance, originality, and clarity. Submissions should be organized to communicate clearly to a broad programming-language audience as well as experts on the paper’s topics. Papers should identify what has been accomplished and how it relates to previous work. Authors of empirical papers are encouraged to consider the seven categories of the SIGPLAN Empirical Evaluation Guidelines when preparing submissions.

### Double-Blind Reviewing

Author names and affiliations must be omitted from submissions. If a submission refers to prior work done by the authors, that reference should be made in third person. Any supplementary material must also be anonymized. These are firm submission requirements. The Review Committee will only learn the identities of authors of accepted papers following the second round of reviewing.

The [FAQ on Double-Blind Reviewing](https://pldi25.sigplan.org/faq/FAQ-on-Double-Blind-Reviewing) clarifies the policy for the most common scenarios. In complex cases, it is better to get guidance from the Associate Editor than to risk summary rejection.

### Author Response

Authors will be given several days to compose a written response to the reviews received in the first round – e.g., to correct errors and clarify technical concerns. In the second round, authors of conditionally-accepted papers will be given an opportunity to improve specific aspects of the research and the paper, as identified by the reviewers.

### Artifact Evaluation

Authors of accepted papers will be invited to submit supporting materials to the Artifact Evaluation process. Artifact Evaluation is run by a separate committee whose task is to assess how well the artifacts support the work described in the papers. Authors of accepted papers are encouraged to make their artifacts publicly available upon publication of the proceedings, by including them as “source materials” in the ACM Digital Library.

## Supplementary Material

Authors are welcome to provide supplementary material if that material supports the claims in the paper. Such material may include proofs, experimental results, and/or data sets. This material should be uploaded at the same time as the submission. Reviewers are not required to examine the supplementary material but may refer to it if they would like to find further evidence supporting the claims in the paper.

Supplemental material cannot be included in the main submission text. All appendices must be submitted as supplemental material, not as part of the main submission PDF.

## Plagiarism and Concurrent Work

Papers must describe unpublished work that is not currently submitted for publication elsewhere, as described by the SIGPLAN Republication Policy and ACM Policy on Plagiarism. Concurrent submissions to other conferences, workshops, journals, or similar venues of publication are disallowed. Prior work must, as always, be cited and referred to in the third person even if it is the authors’ own work, so as to preserve author anonymity.

## Open Access and Copyright

As a Gold Open Access journal, PACMPL is committed to making peer-reviewed scientific research free of restrictions on both access and (re-)use. Authors are strongly encouraged to support liberal open access by licensing their work with the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY) license, which grants readers (re-)use rights.

Authors of accepted papers will be required to provide an ORCID for each co-author and choose one of the following publication rights: (1) Author licenses the work with a Creative Commons license, retains copyright, and grants ACM non-exclusive permission to publish (suggested choice); (2) Author retains copyright of the work and grants ACM a non-exclusive permission to publish license; (3) Author retains copyright of the work and grants ACM an exclusive permission to publish license; (4) Author transfers copyright of the work to ACM.

While PACMPL may ask authors who have funding for open-access fees to voluntarily cover the article processing charge (currently, US$400), payment is not required for publication.

## Presentations and Awards

### Presentations

Authors of accepted papers will be invited to present their work at PLDI. Authors who need financial assistance for travel to the conferences should apply for a grant from the SIGPLAN Professional Activities Committee (PAC) program. If authors are not able to obtain visas to travel to the conference despite making reasonable effort, we will make arrangements to facilitate remote participation or presentation by another attendee on behalf of the authors.

### Distinguished Paper Awards

Up to 10% of the accepted papers may be designated as Distinguished Papers. This award highlights papers that the Review Committee believes should be read by a broad audience due to their relevance, originality, significance, and clarity.

## Code of Conduct

PLDI follows the ACM Policy Against Harassment at ACM Activities. Please familiarize yourself with the policy and guide for reporting unacceptable behavior.

If you witness or are subject to unacceptable behavior, please contact SIGPLAN’s Committee to Aid REporting (CARES) by contacting one of the listed persons, such as Steve Blackburn (steve.blackburn@anu.edu.au).

## Contact Information

For questions regarding double-blind rules or complex cases not covered by the FAQ, please contact the Associate Editor.

callForPapers:
# PLoP 2025: Call for Submissions

Pattern Languages of Programs (PLoP™) is the premier event for pattern authors and enthusiasts to gather, discuss, and learn more about patterns, design, software development, and the built world in general.

PLoP 2025 welcomes paper authors and nonauthors alike. Writers’ Workshops offer authors the opportunity to improve their papers, while "Imagination Run Wild" sessions offer everyone, including newcomers, an opportunity to learn about patterns and related topics.

## Submission Types

### PAPERS

*   **DUE: June 9 (Extended)**
*   **Content:** Papers describing patterns and pattern languages, experience reports, essays, empirical evaluations, reflections, etc.
*   **Process:**
    1.  **Submission:** Assessed for suitability and quality by the program committee.
    2.  **Shepherding:** Each suitable paper is assigned a shepherd to help the author revise and improve the paper through several iterations.
    3.  **Peer Review:** After shepherding, papers are assessed again by the program committee. Acceptance considers author's willingness to incorporate feedback.
    4.  **Writers’ Workshops:** Accepted papers are discussed in workshops at the conference for further improvement.
    5.  **Final Submission:** Authors make final improvements after the conference for the proceedings.
*   **Author Responsibility:** At least one author of an accepted paper must register for the conference. Failure to register will result in acceptance being withdrawn.
*   **Contact for Papers:** Hugo Ferreira, papers program chair ([ploppapers@hillside.net](mailto:ploppapers@hillside.net))
*   **Submission Link:** [https://submission.plopcon.org/plop/2025/submission/gate.cgi](https://submission.plopcon.org/plop/2025/submission/gate.cgi)

### IMAGINATION RUN WILD

*   **DUE: July 15**
*   **Content:** Proposals for hour-long presentations, 5-minute lightning talks, workshops/focus groups, open spaces, fishbowls, or birds-of-a-feather sessions.
*   **Flexibility:** The conference organizers are open to receiving a variety of session types and activities. If you wish to propose an activity that does not fit into any of the mentioned formats, please contact Kiyoka Hayashi, the “Imagination Run Wild” program chair.
*   **Publication:** Reports from these sessions may be included in the conference proceedings (subject to review).
*   **Contact for Imagination Run Wild:** Kiyoka Hayashi ([plopirw@hillside.net](mailto:plopirw@hillside.net))
*   **Submission Link:** [https://submission.plopcon.org/plop/2025/submission/gate.cgi](https://submission.plopcon.org/plop/2025/submission/gate.cgi)

## Important Dates (All times AoE - Anytime on Earth)

*   **June 9:** Paper submissions due (Extended!)
*   **June 15:** Notification of acceptance for shepherding. Paper authors will be notified.
*   **July 15:** Updated papers due.
*   **July 15:** Imagination Run Wild submissions due.
*   **July 30:** Notification of acceptance sent for all submissions.
*   **August 10:** Early registration ends. Fee increases, and lodging is subject to availability. **All paper authors and Imagination Run Wild facilitators must register by this date.**
*   **September 23:** Conference version of paper due.
*   **January 15 (2026):** Proceedings version of paper and Imagination Run Wild reports due.

## Funding and Costs

The Hillside organization is a nonprofit that does not have funding for PLoP travel, registration, and lodging. **All attendees are responsible for these costs.**

## Registration

[REGISTRATION](https://plopcon.org/plop2025/registration/)

callForPapers:
# PKC 2025: Call for Papers

## General Information

PKC 2025 will take place in **Røros, Norway** from **May 12-15, 2025**. The conference is organized by [the International Association for Cryptologic Research (IACR)](https://iacr.org/) and NTNU. The proceedings will be published by Springer in the LNCS series.

Original research papers on all aspects of public-key cryptography, covering theory, implementations and applications, and related fields, are solicited for submission to PKC 2025.

### Topics of Interest

Areas of interest include research on:

*   public key schemes, such as their design and analysis (including side channel attacks), from its math to actual systems
*   the design, proposal, and analysis of cryptographic primitives and protocols
*   public-key techniques in MPC or other protocols

This year, the conference particularly welcomes submissions on the theme of **“Real-world public-key cryptography.”**

*Note: Pure information-theoretic and symmetric-key subjects, e.g., block cipher design and attacks, are not in scope.*

## Submission Guidelines

*   Submissions must be at most **30 pages** excluding any auxiliary supporting material and references.
*   Submissions must use the **Springer LNCS format**. Details on the Springer LNCS format can be obtained [here](https://www.springer.com/gp/authors-editors/book-authors-editors/manuscript-preparation/publishers-author-guidelines).
*   It is strongly encouraged that submissions are processed in LaTeX.
*   All submissions must have page numbers (e.g., using LaTeX command \pagestyle{plain}).
*   Submissions must be submitted electronically in **PDF format**.
*   All submissions will be **blind-refereed** and thus must be anonymous, with no author names, affiliations, acknowledgments, or obvious references.
*   Submissions should begin with a title, a short abstract, and a list of keywords, followed by an introduction and a main body, within 30 pages.
*   Optionally, a clearly-marked auxiliary supporting material can be appended or submitted as a separate file. Reviewers are not required to read this material.
*   Submissions not meeting these guidelines risk rejection without consideration of their merits.

Further details are available on the [paper submission page](papersubmission.php).

## Important Dates

*   **Submission deadline:** Oct 16, 2024 (11:59pm AoE)
*   **First round notification:** Dec 11, 2024
*   **Rebuttal deadline:** Dec 18, 2024
*   **Final notification:** Feb 5, 2025
*   **Final versions due:** Feb 26, 2025
*   **Conference begins:** May 12, 2025

## Review Process

PKC 2025 will operate a two-round review system with a rebuttal phase. The Program Committee selects submissions for a second round after the first round notification, and authors can submit a rebuttal letter. Final decisions are made in the second round, considering the rebuttal.

## Awards

The Program Committee may select a paper for the **best paper award**. Additionally, a prize may be awarded for the **best paper authored exclusively by early-career researchers** (all co-authors must be studying full/part-time or have received their degree in 2019 or later).

## Stipends

Students whose papers are accepted and who present their talks will have their registration waived. A limited number of stipends are available for students unable to obtain funding to attend the conference. Requests should be sent to the general chair.

## Program Committee

*Navid Alamati, Nuttapong Attrapadung, Benedikt Auerbach, Shi Bai, Mihir Bellare, Olivier Blazy, Wouter Castryck, Sofía Celi, Melissa Chase, Rongmao Chen, Yu Chen, Liqun Chen, Sherman Chow, Daniel Collins, Gareth T. Davies, Hannah Davis, Thomas Debris-Alazard, Benjamin Dowling, Rafael Dowsley, Léo Ducas, Nico Döttling, Nils Fleischhacker, Steven D. Galbraith, Kristian Gjøsteen, Aurore Guillevic, Fuchun Guo, Shuai Han, Lucjan Hanzlik, Hans Heum, Kathrin Hövelmanns, Miran Kim, Lisa Kohl, Veronika Kuchta, Sabrina Kunzweiler, Péter Kutas, Russell W. F. Lai, Tanja Lange, Xiangyu Liu, Eleftheria Makri, Mark Manulis, Varun Maram, Alexander May, Adam O'Neill, Miyako Ohkubo, Cristina Onete, Claudio Orlandi, Omkant Pandey, Krzysztof Pietrzak, Bertram Poettering, Sebastian Ramacher, Doreen Riepel, Guilherme Rito, Andy Rupp, Paul Rösler, Amin Sakzad, Dominique Schröder, Jacob C. N. Schuldt, Rebecca Schwerdt, Sven Schäge, Yannick Seurin, Daniel Slamanig, Yongsoo Song, Vanessa Teague, Stefano Tessaro, Daniele Venturi, Benedikt Wagner, Weiqiang Wen, Thom Wiggers, David Wu, Keita Xagawa, Yu Yu, Runzhi Zeng*

## Program Co-chairs

*Tibor Jager, Jiaxin Pan*

*Email: [pkc2025programchairs@iacr.org](mailto:pkc2025programchairs@iacr.org)*

## Area Chairs

*   **Advanced PKE:** Stefano Tessaro
*   **Mathematics of Public-Key Crypto:** Alexander May
*   **MPC and Friends:** Claudio Orlandi
*   **(Real-World) Primitives and Protocols:** Mihir Bellare
*   **Advanced Signatures and Proof Systems:** Miyako Ohkubo

## General Co-chairs

*Bor de Kock, Tjerand Silde*

*Email: [pkc2025@iacr.org](mailto:pkc2025@iacr.org)*

## Conflicts of Interest

Authors, program committee members, and reviewers must follow the [IACR Policy on Conflicts of Interest](https://www.iacr.org/docs/). Automatic conflicts of interest include thesis advisor relationships, recent shared institutional affiliations, multiple jointly authored works, and immediate family members. Authors are responsible for correctly reporting COI information. Submissions with incorrect or incomplete COI information may be rejected. Full transparency and disclosure of any potential bias are expected.

callForPapers:
# POPL 2025: Call for Papers

POPL 2025 seeks contributions on all aspects of programming languages and programming systems, both theoretical and practical.

## Scope

Principles of Programming Languages (POPL) is a forum for the discussion of all aspects of programming languages and programming systems. Both theoretical and experimental papers are welcome, on topics ranging from formal frameworks to experience reports. We seek submissions that make principled, enduring contributions to the theory, design, understanding, implementation, or application of programming languages.

## Evaluation Criteria

The Review Committee will evaluate the technical contribution of each submission as well as its accessibility to both experts and the general POPL audience. All papers will be judged on significance, originality, relevance, correctness, and clarity. Each paper must explain its scientific contribution in both general and technical terms, identifying what has been accomplished, explaining why it is significant, and comparing it with previous work.

## Double-Blind Reviewing

POPL 2025 will use a **full double-blind reviewing process**. This means that identities of authors will not be visible to reviewers until after conditional-acceptance decisions have been made. Authors must omit their names and institutions from their paper submissions and refer to their own prior work in the third person. Supplementary material must also be fully anonymized. Authors should not reveal their identity when responding to reviews.

## Submission Site Information

The submission site is [https://popl25.hotcrp.com/](https://popl25.hotcrp.com/). Authors can submit multiple times prior to the deadline. Only the last submission will be reviewed. There is no abstract deadline.

## Conflicts of Interest

Authors must properly declare all potential conflicts of interest for all authors when submitting. This includes marking PC conflicts as well as "Other Conflicts (external)". Conflicts include adviser-advisee relationships, co-author relationships, colleagues at the same institution, financial conflicts, and relationships with friends or relatives.

## Submission Guidelines

*   Each paper should have no more than **25 pages of text**, excluding bibliography.
*   Use the **PACMPL format** (acmart LaTeX class with acmsmall option). This is a single-column page layout with a 10 pt font, 12 pt line spacing, and wider margins.
*   Submissions should be in **PDF** and printable on both US Letter and A4 paper.
*   Authors are free to submit supplementary material, but it must be fully anonymized.
*   Concurrent paper submissions to other venues are **not allowed**.

## Artifact Evaluation

Authors of conditionally accepted papers will be invited to formally submit supporting materials to the Artifact Evaluation process. Successful artifacts will receive a seal of approval.

## Copyright, Publication, and Presentation

*   PACMPL is a Gold Open Access journal. Authors are encouraged to use the [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY)](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/) license.
*   Authors will choose one of the following publication rights: retain copyright with CC license (suggested), retain copyright with ACM non-exclusive permission, or transfer copyright to ACM.
*   All papers will be archived by the ACM Digital Library.
*   Authors of accepted papers are encouraged to give a short talk (approx. 25 minutes) at the conference.

## Important Dates (AoE - Anywhere on Earth)

*   **Paper submission deadline:** July 11, 2024
*   **Beginning of Author Response Period:** September 11, 2024
*   **End of Author Response:** September 20, 2024
*   **Conditional Accept decisions announced:** October 8, 2024
*   **Authors of conditional accepted papers send their revised versions:** October 25, 2024
*   **Final acceptance notifications sent to authors:** November 7, 2024
*   **Camera ready deadline:** November 22, 2024
*   **Conference:** January 19 - 25, 2025

## Distinguished Paper Awards

At most 10% of accepted papers will be designated as Distinguished Papers.

## Program Committee

*   **PC Chair:** Armando Solar-Lezama (Massachusetts Institute of Technology, USA)
*   **Associate Chairs:** Zachary Kincaid (Princeton University, USA), Xavier Leroy (Collège de France, France), Ruzica Piskac (Yale University, USA), Nadia Polikarpova (University of California at San Diego, USA), Sharon Shoham (Tel Aviv University, Israel)
*   **Committee Members:** Robert Atkey, Arthur Azevedo de Amorim, Sorav Bansal, Ryan Beckett, Filippo Bonchi, Oliver Bračevac, Satish Chandra, Sarah E. Chasins, Sheng Chen, James Cheney, Pierre Clairambault, Adam Chlipala, Albert Cohen, David Darais, Christos Dimoulas, Michael Emmi, Mohamed Faouzi Atig, Azadeh Farzan, Cormac Flanagan, Jeffrey S. Foster, Timon Gehr, Roberta Gori, Neville Grech, Philipp Haller, Jan Hoffmann, Steven Holtzen, Justin Hsu, Gowtham Kaki, Benjamin Lucien Kaminski, Artem Khyzha, Fredrik Kjolstad, Hsiang-Shang ‘Josh’ Ko, Naoki Kobayashi, Eric Koskinen, Leonidas Lampropoulos, Woosuk Lee, Yao Li, P. Madhusudan, Darko Marinov, Roland Meyer, David Monniaux, J. Garrett Morris, Magnus O. Myreen, Hakjoo Oh, Cyrus Omar, Jens Palsberg, Pavel Panchekha, Matthew J. Parkinson, Frank Pfenning, Lauren Pick, Clément Pit-Claudel, Shaz Qadeer, Mukund Raghothaman, Tahina Ramananandro, Xavier Rival, Grigore Roşu, Feras Saad, José Fragoso Santos, Chung-chieh Shan, Zhong Shao, Tachio Terauchi, Aditya V. Thakur, Caterina Urban, Viktor Vafeiadis, Matthijs Vákár, Gabriele Vanoni, Vasco T. Vasconcelos, Margus Veanes, Dimitrios Vytiniotis, Philip Wadler, Xinyu Wang, Peisen Yao, Mingsheng Ying, Vladimir Zamdzhiev, Danfeng Zhang, Damien Zufferey

## Tracks

*   POPL

callForPapers:
# PODS 2025 CALL FOR RESEARCH PAPERS

The Principles of Database Systems (PODS) symposium series, held in conjunction with the SIGMOD conference series, provides a premier annual forum for the communication of new advances in the theoretical foundations of data management. The 2025 conference will be held in **Berlin, Germany**.

## Mission

The PODS community aims to:

*   Provide a solid scientific basis for methods, techniques, and solutions for data management challenges.
*   Develop new ways of advancing data management to reflect the rich landscape of data requirements in applications.
*   Develop solutions that ensure high levels of efficiency, scalability, usability, expressiveness, robustness, security, clarity, and privacy.
*   Foster an open space for researchers from various areas related to the principles of computer science to discuss, interact, and propose solutions to problems in data management.

## Scope

PODS seeks scientific articles that present principled contributions to modeling, application, and system building in the context of data management. Articles may be based on establishing theoretical results, developing new concepts and frameworks, providing experimental work that sheds light on the scientific foundations, or rigorous analysis of important industry artifacts. PODS pays special attention to papers that help integrate data management techniques within broader computer science.

## Topics of Interest

Topics that fit the interests of the symposium include, but are not limited to:

*   Database processing: Query evaluation, query optimization, schema management, distributed data processing, approximate data processing
*   Database design: Data models, query languages, schemas, constraints
*   Database access: Data structures, access methods, concurrency, transactions
*   Data quality: Data consistency, data cleaning, data discovery, data exploration
*   Data analysis: Data mining, machine learning, information extraction, data streams
*   Uncertainty: Incomplete data, inconsistent data, probabilistic data
*   Interoperability: Mappings and views, data integration, data exchange, ontology-based data access
*   Responsible data management: Access control, privacy, security, verification, ethical aspects of data management
*   Human-database interaction: data summarization, data visualization, explanation for database queries
*   Connections between database principles and other disciplines

## Submission Site

[https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=pods2025](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=pods2025)

## Submission Format

*   **Important:** The submission format for PODS 2025 is different from that of previous years, for compatibility with the PACMMOD format of the PODS publications.
*   **LaTex users** must format their submission using the standard ACM "acmsmall" proceedings stylesheet: [https://www.acm.org/publications/proceedings-template](https://www.acm.org/publications/proceedings-template)
*   Class declaration: `\documentclass[acmsmall,review,anonymous]{acmart}`
*   A submission can be up to **15 pages**, not including references, plus unlimited space for references.
*   **Appendix:** Additional details may be included in a clearly marked appendix, of unlimited length, that should be incorporated at submission time. However, an appendix will be read at the discretion of the program committee.
*   Papers that are longer than 15 pages or do not cohere with the required format style risk rejection without consideration of their merits.
*   The results of a submitted paper must be unpublished and not submitted elsewhere.
*   Authors of an accepted paper will be expected to sign copyright release forms, and accepted papers will be published in a PODS 2025 issue of the **PACMMOD** (https://dl.acm.org/journal/pacmmod) journal.

## Double-anonymous reviewing

PODS 2025 will use a lightweight double-anonymous reviewing process. Submissions must adhere to the following:

*   Author names and institutions must be omitted.
*   References to the authors’ own related work should be in the third person.
*   Acknowledgements, grant numbers, and links to submitted papers in public repositories will not be allowed.

Authors are encouraged to disseminate their ideas or draft versions of their paper as they normally would.

## Merit-based acceptance

Paper selection will be merit-based, judged on originality, quality, clarity of presentation, relevance to the field, and technical depth. There is no a priori limit on the number of accepted papers.

## Important Dates

All deadlines end at **5 PM Pacific Time**.

### First Submission Cycle

1.  **Abstract deadline:** May 31, 2024
2.  **Full paper submission deadline:** June 7, 2024
3.  **Rebuttal:** July 29 - August 1, 2024
4.  **Initial notification:** August 12, 2024
5.  **Revision submission:** August 26, 2024
6.  **Final notification:** September 2, 2024

### Second Submission Cycle

1.  **Abstract deadline:** December 2, 2024
2.  **Full paper submission deadline:** December 9, 2024
3.  **Rebuttal:** February 3-7, 2025
4.  **Initial notification:** February 14, 2025
5.  **Revision submission:** February 28, 2025
6.  **Final notification:** March 7, 2025

callForPapers:
# SoCS 2025: Call for Papers

The 18th International Symposium on Combinatorial Search (SoCS 2025) will be held from **August 12-15, 2025**, at the **University of Glasgow, Scotland, United Kingdom**. The symposium is co-located with the 31st International Conference on Principles and Practice of Constraint Programming (CP 2025) and the 18th International Conference on Theory and Applications of Satisfiability Testing (SAT 2025).

**Submissions are now closed.**

## Overview

Heuristic search and other forms of combinatorial search and optimization are active research areas in artificial intelligence, robotics, planning, constraint programming, meta-reasoning, navigation, bioinformatics, and other fields. SoCS aims to foster collaboration and idea exchange among researchers in these areas. Submissions presenting real-world applications of heuristic search are particularly encouraged.

## Topics of Interest

Topics of interest include but are not limited to:

*   Adversarial search
*   Analysis of search algorithms
*   Automated synthesis of lower bounds
*   Bidirectional search
*   Bounding and pruning techniques
*   Combinatorial optimization
*   Combinatorial puzzles
*   Continuous problem solving
*   Constraint search
*   Deep learning in heuristics and search
*   External-memory and parallel search
*   Heuristics
*   Incremental and active learning in search
*   Machine learning for or in search algorithms
*   Metareasoning and search
*   Methodology and critiques of current practice
*   Model-based search
*   Multi-agent pathfinding
*   Pathfinding
*   Portfolios of search algorithms
*   Problem compilation
*   Problem solving using search
*   Random vs. systematic search strategy selection
*   Real-life applications
*   Real-time search
*   Reinforcement learning and search
*   Search in goal-directed problem solving
*   Search space discretization for continuous state-space problems
*   Search-based diagnosis
*   Search in boolean satisfiability
*   Search in machine learning and big data analytics
*   Search methods in robotics
*   Self-configuring and self-tuning algorithms
*   Symmetry handling
*   Time, memory, and solution quality trade-offs

## Types of Submissions

*   **Technical papers:** Original long (up to 8 pages plus up to one page of references) and short (up to 4 pages plus up to one page of references) papers reporting substantial original research.
*   **Position papers:** Original long (up to 8 pages plus up to one page of references) and short (up to 4 pages plus up to one page of references) papers discussing ideas and concepts related to heuristic and combinatorial search.
*   **Extended abstracts:** (up to 2 pages, including references) for original work, work-in-progress, or recently published/under-review work.

## Submission Instructions

*   Submissions must be original and not submitted concurrently to a journal or another conference.
*   **Double-blind reviewing** will be provided; submitted papers must omit author names and affiliations (except for specific cases of extended abstracts).
*   The submission process involves registering the paper abstract in EasyChair first, followed by the full paper submission.
*   Supplementary material (video, appendices) may be submitted but must also be anonymized.

## Important Dates (Regular Submissions)

*   **Paper abstract submission deadline:** March 19, 2025 (Closed)
*   **Paper submission deadline:** March 26, 2025 (Closed)
*   **Author response:** May 2-5, 2025 (Past)
*   **Notification:** May 16, 2025
*   **Camera-ready copy:** May 30, 2025

*All deadlines are at 23:59 UTC-12.*

## Awards

*   Best paper award
*   Best student paper award (for eligible papers)

## Registration

*   **Early registration:** until June 30, 2025
*   **Late registration:** closes July 31, 2025

callForPapers:
# SOSP 2025: Call for Papers

The 31st ACM Symposium on Operating Systems Principles (SOSP) invites submissions presenting innovative and exciting research related to the design, implementation, analysis, evaluation, and deployment of computer systems software.

## Where and When

*   **Venue:** Lotte Hotel World, Seoul, Republic of Korea
*   **Dates:** Monday to Thursday, October 13 – 16, 2025

## Important Dates

*   **Deadline to register abstracts:** April 10, 2025; 23:59 PT
*   **Submission deadline (no extensions):** April 17, 2025; 23:59 PT
*   **Reviews available for author response:** July 1, 2025
*   **Author response due:** July 3, 2025
*   **Author notification:** July 15, 2025
*   **Camera ready due:** TBD
*   **Workshop/Tutorial Proposals Due:** April 29, 2025
*   **Workshop/Tutorial Notification of Acceptance:** May 4, 2025

## Topics of Interest

SOSP takes a broad view of systems and solicits contributions from many fields of systems practice, including:

*   operating systems
*   file and storage systems
*   distributed systems
*   cloud computing
*   mobile and edge systems
*   secure and reliable systems
*   systems aspects of big data and machine learning
*   embedded and real-time systems
*   virtualization
*   networking as it relates to operating systems
*   management and troubleshooting of complex systems

We also welcome work that explores the interaction of computer systems with related areas such as computer architecture, networking, programming languages, analytics, verification, and databases.

## Submission Criteria

Submissions will be judged on novelty, significance, interest, clarity, relevance, and correctness. A good paper will:

*   Motivate a significant problem;
*   Propose and implement an interesting, compelling solution;
*   Demonstrate the practicality and benefits of the solution;
*   Draw appropriate conclusions;
*   Clearly describe the paper's contributions;
*   Articulate the advances beyond previous work; and
*   Be accessible to the broader systems community.

## Originality and Resubmissions

*   Submissions should contain original, unpublished material. Simultaneous submission of the same work to multiple venues, submission of previously published work, or plagiarism is not allowed.
*   Submissions that extend the authors' previous work are welcome, but authors must explain the differences.
*   Prior or concurrent publication in non-peer-reviewed contexts, like arXiv.org, technical reports, talks, and social media posts, is explicitly permitted.
*   Submitting a paper that was previously submitted to another conference is permitted, provided authors have improved the paper and provide details of revisions.

## Anonymity

SOSP will use **double-blind reviewing**. Please make a good faith attempt to anonymize your submission. Avoid identifying yourself or your institution explicitly or by implication. The first page should use the paper ID assigned during registration. Reference your own past work in the third person.

## Formatting

*   Submissions must be in PDF format.
*   Maximum **12 pages** of technical content (including figures, tables, etc.). Bibliographic references are not included in the page limit.
*   Use A4 or US letter paper size, with text and figures fitting inside a 178 x 229 mm (7 x 9 in) block.
*   Two columns separated by 8 mm (0.33 in) whitespace.
*   10-point font on 12-point leading.
*   Graphs and figures should be readable without magnification, preferably in color but readable in grayscale.
*   All pages should be numbered, and references within the paper should be hyperlinked.
*   Violations of formatting rules will not be considered for publication.
*   Recommended to use the official SIGPLAN LaTeX or MS Word templates from ACM.

## Submission

Papers must be submitted electronically in PDF format via the [HotCRP Submission Site](https://sosp25.hotcrp.com/).

## Questions

Any questions about paper submissions can be emailed to sosp2025@gmail.com.

callForPapers:
# Call for Papers - IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy (SP)

The 46th IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy (SP) will be held from **May 12-15, 2025**, at the **Hyatt Regency San Francisco, San Francisco, CA**.

Since 1980, the IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy has been the premier forum for presenting developments in computer security and electronic privacy, and for bringing together researchers and practitioners in the field.

## Topics of Interest

We solicit previously unpublished papers offering novel research contributions in any aspect of security or privacy. Papers may present advances in the theory, design, implementation, analysis, verification, or empirical evaluation and measurement of secure systems. Theoretical papers must make a convincing case for the relevance of their results to practice.

Topics include:

*   Applied cryptography
*   Attacks with novel insights, techniques, or results
*   Authentication, access control, and authorization
*   Blockchains and distributed ledger security
*   Cloud computing security
*   Cyber physical systems security
*   Distributed systems security
*   Economics of security and privacy
*   Embedded systems security
*   Formal methods and verification
*   Hardware security
*   Hate, Harassment, and Online Abuse
*   Human-centered security and privacy
*   Intrusion detection and prevention
*   Machine learning and computer security
*   Malware and unwanted software
*   Network security and measurement
*   Operating systems security
*   Privacy-enhancing technologies, anonymity, and censorship
*   Program and binary analysis
*   Protocol security
*   Security and privacy metrics
*   Security and privacy policies
*   Security architectures
*   Security for at-risk populations
*   Software supply chain security
*   Systems security
*   User studies for security and privacy
*   Web security and privacy
*   Wireless and mobile security/privacy

This list is not exhaustive. Papers without a clear application to security or privacy may be rejected without full review.

## Systematization of Knowledge (SoK) Papers

We also solicit SoK papers that evaluate, systematize, and contextualize existing knowledge, providing important new viewpoints, challenging long-held beliefs, or presenting convincing taxonomies. Survey papers without such insights are not appropriate.

*   Submissions should be prefixed with "**SoK:**" in the title and indicate SoK status on the submission form.
*   Reviewed by the full PC and held to the same standards as traditional research papers.

## Submission Deadlines & Decisions

**First Deadline:**

*   Paper submission deadline: **June 6, 2024**
*   Early-reject notification: **July 22, 2024**
*   Rebuttal period (interactive): August 19 - August 30, 2024
*   Rebuttal text due: August 26, 2024
*   Acceptance notification: **September 9, 2024**
*   Camera-ready deadline: **October 18, 2024**

**Second Deadline:**

*   Paper submission deadline: **November 14, 2024**
*   Early-reject notification: **January 20, 2025**
*   Rebuttal period (interactive): February 17 - February 28, 2025
*   Rebuttal text due: February 24, 2025
*   Acceptance notification: **March 10, 2025**
*   Camera-ready deadline: **April 18, 2025**

## Public Meta-Reviews

Accepted papers will include a meta-review (< 500 words) listing acceptance reasons and PC concerns. Authors can provide a response (< 500 words). A shepherd will remove concerns if addressed by revisions.

## Symposium Event Changes

Each accepted paper will have:

*   A short talk presentation (e.g., 5-7 minutes).
*   A poster presentation immediately following the talk session.
*   All accepted papers are required to present both.

## Rebuttal Period

Papers in the second round will have an interactive rebuttal period with reviewers via HotCRP's anonymous communication feature. Focus on factual errors and concrete questions. New research results can be discussed if they clarify open questions.

## Resubmission of Rejected Papers

Rejected papers must wait one year before resubmission to IEEE S&P. Rejected papers are eligible for submission according to the following table:

| 2024 deadlines | Reject decision | Eligible 2025 deadlines |
|---|---|---|
| First 2024 (April 13, 2023) | Any | Either 2025 deadline |
| Second 2024 (August 3, 2023) | Any | Either 2025 deadline |
| Third 2024 (Dec 6, 2023) | Any | Second deadline (Nov 14, 2024) |

## Instructions for Paper Submission

*   All submissions must be original work; document any overlap with previously published or simultaneously submitted papers. Failure to do so may result in rejection.
*   Simultaneous submission to another venue with proceedings or a journal is not allowed.

### Anonymous Submission

*   Papers must be submitted for anonymous review: no author names or affiliations on the title page, and authors should avoid revealing their identity in the text.
*   Cite own work in the third person without identifying yourself. Blind references if necessary.
*   Papers not properly anonymized may be rejected without review.

Authors may give talks, post preprints to repositories (e.g., arXiv), and disclose vulnerabilities during submission. Contact PC chairs for exceptions.

## Conflicts of Interest

Authors must identify all potential conflicts of interest with PC members during submission. A conflict exists if:

*   The PC member is a co-author.
*   The PC member has been a co-worker in the same company or university within the past two years.
*   The PC member has been a collaborator within the past two years.
*   The PC member is or was the author’s primary thesis advisor.
*   The author is or was the PC member’s primary thesis advisor.
*   The PC member is a relative or close personal friend.

Explain any other conflicts to the PC chairs. Incorrect or incomplete conflict of interest information may lead to immediate rejection.

## Research Ethics Committee (REC)

Papers flagged by reviewers may be checked by the REC. Authors are encouraged to review the Menlo Report for ethical guidelines.

### Ethical Considerations for Vulnerability Disclosure

*   When identifying vulnerabilities, avoid gratuitous harm and protect users. Disclose to vendors and stakeholders.
*   A disclosure window of **45 to 90 days** ahead of publication is recommended.
*   Submitters must discuss steps taken or planned to address vulnerabilities. Full CVE identifiers should not be included in review submissions.

### Ethical Considerations for Human Subjects Research

*   Disclose IRB approval or waiver status if applicable.
*   Discuss steps taken to ensure ethical treatment of participants.
*   If dealing with personal identifiable information (PII) or sensitive data, detail steps taken to mitigate harms.

Papers raising significant ethical/legal concerns may be rejected.

## Financial and Non-financial Competing Interests

Authors must declare any competing interests in the camera-ready versions of their papers.

## Page Limit and Formatting

*   Submitted papers: up to **13 pages of text** + up to **5 pages for references and appendices** (total **18 pages**).
*   All text and figures past page 13 must be clearly marked as part of the appendix.
*   Final camera-ready paper: no more than 18 pages (PC chairs may allow more).
*   Papers must be formatted for **US letter** size paper.
*   **All submissions must use the IEEE “compsoc” conference proceedings template.** Use `IEEEtran.cls` version 1.8b with options "conference,compsoc.".
*   Papers not using the correct template, modifying margins, font, or line spacing, or using egregious space scrunching are subject to rejection without review.

## Withdrawing Policy

A paper can be withdrawn at any point before reviews are sent to authors. After reviews are sent, withdrawal is not permitted.

## Authorship Policy

Changes to authorship are not permitted after submission. Changes to affiliation after acceptance require PC chairs approval.

## Conference Submission Server

Submissions must be in Portable Document Format (.pdf).

*   First deadline server: [https://cycle1.sp2025.ieee-security.org/](https://cycle1.sp2025.ieee-security.org/)
*   Second deadline server: [https://cycle2.sp2025.ieee-security.org/](https://cycle2.sp2025.ieee-security.org/)

## Publication and Presentation

Authors are responsible for obtaining publication clearances. One author must register and present the paper at the conference.

## Organizing Committee Highlights

*   **General Chair:** Marina Blanton
*   **Program Chairs:** William Enck, Cristina Nita-Rotaru
*   **Treasurer:** Adwait Nadkarni
*   **Workshops Chairs:** Ziming Zhao, Gang Wang
*   **Short Talks Chair:** Bradley Reaves
*   **Posters Chair:** Kassem Fawaz

(Full list of committee members available on the conference website.)

callForPapers:
# Call For Papers

The **37th ACM Symposium on Parallelism in Algorithms and Architectures (SPAA ’25)** will run from **July 28—August 1, 2025**, in **Portland, Oregon**.

SPAA ’25 is sponsored by the ACM Special Interest Groups on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT) and Computer Architecture (SIGARCH) and organized in cooperation with the European Association for Theoretical Computer Science (EATCS).

## Submission Site

Papers will be submitted through HotCRP on the [submission site](https://spaa25.hotcrp.com).

## Topics of Interest

Submissions are sought in all areas of parallel and distributed computing, including algorithms, data structures, computational models, complexity theory, architectures, performance engineering, languages, runtime systems, compilers, programming systems, and networking systems. Papers that are purely theoretical, purely experimental, or contain both theory and experiments are welcome.

Topics of interest include, but are not limited to:

*   Parallel and Distributed Algorithms
*   Parallel, Concurrent, and Distributed Data Structures
*   Models for Parallel and Distributed Computing
*   Parallel and Distributed Architectures
*   Parallel Programming Languages
*   System Software for Parallel and Concurrent Programming (including but not limited to Runtime, Compilers, and Tools)
*   Parallel Programming Frameworks and Domain-Specific Languages
*   Management of Massive Data Sets
*   Transactional Memory Hardware and Software
*   Supercomputer Architecture and Computing
*   Routing and Information Dissemination
*   Peer-to-Peer Systems
*   Mobile, Ad-Hoc, and Sensor Networks
*   Synergy of Parallelism in Algorithms, Programming and Architecture
*   Memory or I/O-efficient algorithms
*   Parallel Complexity Theory
*   Green Computing & Power-Efficient Architectures
*   Instruction Level Parallelism and VLSI
*   Scheduling Algorithms for Parallel Machines
*   Parallelism in Quantum Computing

## Submission Guidelines

### Paper Types

*   **Regular Papers:** Must report on original research that has not been previously or concurrently published.
    *   Maximum **20 pages** of text (excluding bibliography).
    *   Format: ACM “acmsmall” format using the `acmart` LaTeX class. This is a single-column page layout with a **10 pt font** and **12 pt line spacing**. The main text block should be **5.478 inches (13.91 cm) wide** and **7.884 inches (20.03 cm) tall**.
    *   Supplementary material is allowed, but reviewers are not obligated to read it.
*   **Brief Announcements:** Suitable for work in progress, tools/libraries, challenge problems, corrections, or smaller results.
    *   Maximum **six single-column pages** (excluding bibliography).

### Theory vs. Experiments

Submissions must be categorized as:

*   **A. Theory** (main contributions are theoretical)
*   **B. Experiments** (main contributions are experimental)
*   **C. Theory and Experiments** (main contributions are a mix of theory and experiments)

Please indicate the category during the submission process.

### Formatting

Submissions must use the final ACM “acmsmall” format from [https://www.acm.org/publications/proceedings-template](https://www.acm.org/publications/proceedings-template). More details are at [https://spaa.acm.org/submission-guidelines/](https://spaa.acm.org/submission-guidelines/).

## Review Process

SPAA 2025 will employ a **lightweight double-blind review process**.

*   Submissions should omit authors’ names, affiliations, and contact information.
*   References to prior work by the authors should be made in the third person.
*   Any supplemental materials should also be anonymized.
*   Authors are free to disseminate their ideas or draft versions of the paper (e.g., via arXiv or talks).
*   Reviewers will be asked to refrain from actively looking for the identity of the authors via web search.

## Conflict of Interest Policy

Authors must register their conflicts with PC members at the submission site. Conflicts include:

*   Academic advisor or advisee (no time limit)
*   Postdoctoral mentor or mentee (no time limit)
*   Collaborators within the past three years (joint research, development, paper, or funding)
*   Members of the same institution within the past 3 years
*   Family members or close friends
*   Someone involved in an alleged incident of harassment
*   Anyone whose relationship would prevent objectivity

False declarations risk rejection. Contact the program chair for clarification or unlisted valid reasons for conflict.

## Important Deadlines

All times are **11:59pm AoE (Anywhere on Earth)** unless otherwise specified.

*   **Abstract Registration:** February 21, 2025
*   **Full Papers Submission:** February 28, 2025
*   **Rebuttal Period:** April 27–May 3, 2025
*   **Notification:** May 20, 2025
*   **Camera-ready:** June 20, 2025

## Awards

*   SPAA Best Paper Award
*   SPAA Test-of-Time Award
*   SPAA Parallel Computing Award

## Other Information

*   **VISA Support:** Fill out the ACM form here for VISA support letters.
*   **Hotel Booking:** [Link for SPAA Hotel Booking](https://www.hilton.com/en/book/reservation/rooms/?ctyhocn=RLLC-DT&arrivalDate=2025-07-27&departureDate=2025-08-02&groupCode=CDTSPA&room1NumAdults=1&cid=OM%2CWW%2CHILTONLINK%2CEN%2CDirectLink.+Cut-off+date%3A+July+7%2C+2025) (Cut-off date: July 7, 2025)
*   **Registration:** [SPAA registration](https://web.cvent.com/event/998b149e-594c-4d59-8c77-ae35e00e49b2/summary)
*   **Policy:** SPAA follows the ACM anti-harassment policy.

callForPapers:
# SPIRE 2025: Call for Papers

The 32nd International Symposium on String Processing and Information Retrieval (SPIRE 2025) will be held in **London, UK, from September 08 - 11, 2025**.

## Scope

SPIRE 2025 covers research in all aspects of string processing, information retrieval, computational biology, and related applications. Typical topics of interest include (but are not limited to):

*   **String Processing:** string pattern matching, text indexing, data structures for string processing, text compression, compressed data structures, compressed string processing, text mining, 2D pattern matching, automata based string processing, combinatorics on words.
*   **Computational Biology:** algorithms for DNA sequencing, assembly, alignments, read error correction, metagenomics, transcriptomics, gene and regulatory element recognition, motif finding, pangenomics, variants discovery, phylogenetics, genome rearrangements.
*   **Information Retrieval:** Retrieval models and ranking. Theoretical models and foundations of IR. Efficiency and scalability topics in IR. Knowledge acquisition in IR. Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing for IR. Knowledge representation and reasoning for IR. User-centric aspects of IR. IR Evaluation. Fairness, accountability, transparency in IR. Domain-specific IR applications. Web search.

## Submissions

SPIRE 2025 invites submissions in two categories:

*   **Long papers:** Up to 12 pages, excluding references and optional appendices.
*   **Short papers:** Up to 6 pages, excluding references and optional appendices.

Papers should be submitted electronically via EasyChair via the following link: [https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=spire2025](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=spire2025)

As in past editions, the proceedings of SPIRE 2025 will be published by Springer in the Lecture Notes in Computer Science (LNCS) series. The use of LNCS templates is mandatory. Suitable templates are available at the Springer Website and on Overleaf. Do not change the margin size or the font, do not make a separate title page, etc.: use the LNCS style file as given.

Simultaneous submissions to other conferences with published proceedings is not permitted.

At least one author per accepted paper is expected to register for the conference and present the paper. The conference will be in-person, with online presentations only in special cases (e.g., authors with travel difficulties).

## Important Dates

*   **Papers deadline:**
    *   May 29, 2025 AoE (abstract deadline)
    *   June 5, 2025 AoE (firm deadline)
*   **Notifications:** July 17, 2025
*   **Camera-ready due:** TBC
*   **Early bird registration:** TBC

## Events

*   SPIRE: September 08 to 10, 2025
*   Workshop on Compression, Text, and Algorithms (WCTA): September 11, 2025

## Invited Speakers

*   Hideo Bannai, Institute of Science Tokyo, Japan
*   Camille Marchet, CNRS, Lille, France
*   Rajeev Raman, University of Leicester, UK

## General Chairs

*   Golnaz Badkobeh, City St George’s, University of London, UK
*   Ricardo Baeza-Yates, Barcelona Supercomputing Center, Barcelona, Spain

## Program Committee Chairs

*   Golnaz Badkobeh, City St George’s, University of London, UK
*   Jakub Radoszewski, University of Warsaw, Poland
*   Nicola Tonellotto, University of Pisa, Italy

callForPapers:
# Symposium on Solid and Physical Modelling (SPM) 2025: Call for Papers

The Symposium on Solid and Physical Modeling (SPM) 2025 will be held in **Hangzhou, Zhejiang, P.R. China, from October 29 to November 02, 2025**. SPM 2025 will be co-located with **Shape Modeling International (SMI 2025)**.

The conference aims to cover all aspects of geometric and physical modeling, and their application in design, analysis and manufacturing, as well as in biomedical, geophysical, digital entertainment, and other areas. The conference also serves as a ceremony for awarding the 2025 Pierre Bézier Prize for contributions to solid, shape, and physical modeling.

## Scope

Topics of interest include, but are not limited to:

*   3D fabrication/printing/manufacturing technologies
*   Anisotropic/heterogeneous/composite materials
*   Applied algebraic and differential geometry
*   Applied computational geometry and topology
*   Conceptual, collaborative, and distributed design
*   Computational fabrication
*   Curve, surface, and manifold modeling
*   Dimensioning and tolerancing
*   Feature modeling, recognition, and understanding
*   Geometric algorithms
*   Geometric and topological representations
*   Geometric constraint solving and parametric modeling
*   Geometric interpolation and smoothing
*   Geometry generation and processing
*   Geometry compression and transmission
*   Isogeometric analysis
*   Meshing and mesh optimization
*   Multi-resolution modeling
*   Numerical analysis of geometric algorithms
*   Physically-based modeling and simulation
*   Product data exchange, standards, and interoperability
*   Reverse engineering/reconstruction of surfaces/solids
*   Robustness and validity of geometric computations
*   Shape modeling, synthesis and analysis

## Paper Submissions

Accepted full-length papers will be published in the journal of **Computer-Aided Design (Elsevier)** after a rigorous two-stage double-blind review process.

*   Papers should not exceed **12 pages**, including figures and references.
*   We strongly recommend using the [LaTeX template](https://spmconf.github.io/SPM2024/SPM2024_Template.zip) or papers formatted by MS Word according to the style guidelines for Computer-Aided Design (Elsevier).
*   The file must be submitted in PDF format using the [EasyChair website](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=spm20250).
*   All papers must be original and not simultaneously submitted to another journal or conference.
*   You can submit a video, code, or any other supplementary materials as a single zip file (optional).

## Important Dates

*   **Abstract Deadline:** March 08, 2025
*   **Full paper deadline:** March 15, 2025
*   **First review notification:** April 25, 2025
*   **Revised papers due:** May 30, 2025
*   **Final notification:** August 10, 2025
*   **Camera ready papers:** July 30, 2025
*   **Conference:** October 29 – November 02, 2025

## Committees

### Program Committee

*   Yunbo Zhang (Rochester Institute of Technology, USA)
*   Xiaohu Guo (The University of Texas at Dallas, USA)
*   Lucia Romani (Università di Bologna, Italy)

### Organizing committee

*   Weiwei Xu (Zhejiang University, China)
*   Gang Xu (Hangzhou Dianzi University, China)

## Contact

All questions about submissions should be emailed to:

*   Yunbo Zhang (ywzeie@rit.edu)
*   Xiaohu Guo (xguo@utdallas.edu)
*   Lucia Romani (lucia.romani@unibo.it)
